Segundo informou nessa quinta-feira a procuradoria local, os paradeiros dos tr\u00eas s\u00e3o desconhecidos desde o s\u00e1bado, dia 27 de abril.\nEles s\u00e3o os irm\u00e3os australianos Jake e Callum Robinson e seu amigo americano Jack Carter, f\u00e3s de surf que estavam de f\u00e9rias no balne\u00e1rio de Rosarito.\nOs estrangeiros nunca chegaram ao a", "zho": "\uff08\u6cd5\u65b0\u793e\u58a8\u897f\u54e5\u8482\u83ef\u7d0d5\u65e5\u96fb\uff09 \u58a8\u897f\u54e5\u6aa2\u5bdf\u5b98\u4eca\u5929\u8868\u793a\uff0c\u7d93\u5bb6\u5c6c\u8fa8\u8a8d\uff0c\u5728\u58a8\u570b\u897f\u5317\u90e8\u627e\u5230\u76843\u5177\u907a\u9ad4\u8b49\u5be6\u70ba\u5728\u885d\u6d6a\u4e4b\u65c5\u4e2d\u5931\u8e64\u7684\u4e00\u5c0d\u6fb3\u6d32\u5144\u5f1f\u548c1\u540d\u7f8e\u570b\u4eba\u3002\n\n\u8072\u660e\u6307\u51fa\uff0c\u6aa2\u5bdf\u5b98\u8fa6\u516c\u5ba4\u8b49\u5be6\uff0c\u5728\u4e0b\u52a0\u5229\u798f\u5c3c\u4e9e\u5dde\uff08Baja California\uff09\u6069\u745f\u7d0d\u9054\uff08Ensenada\uff09\u4ee5\u5357\u5730\u5340\u4e00\u8655\u4e95\u4e2d\u767c\u73fe\u76843\u5177\u907a\u9ad4\uff0c\u5206\u5225\u70ba\u4f86\u81ea\u6fb3\u6d32\u7684\u5144\u5f1f\u6a94\u5361\u52d2\u59c6\uff0e\u7f85\u8cd3\u68ee\u8207\u5091\u514b\uff0e\u7f85\u8cd3\u68ee\uff08Callum and Jake Robinson\uff09\uff0c\u4ee5\u53ca\u4ed6\u5011\u7684\u7f8e\u570b\u53cb\u4eba\u5361", "ita": "Ritrovati i corpi di tre surfisti - uno statunitense e due australiani - scomparsi in Messico. Avevano ferite d'arma da fuoco alla testa.\n\nLe indagini\n\nUna delle piste seguite dagli investigatori \u00e8 quella di un tentativo di furto del pick-up dei turisti, apparentemente finito male. Il veicolo \u00e8 stato ritrovato bruciato non lontano dai corpi dei due fratelli australiani, Jake e Callum Robinson, e dell'americano Jack Carter.\n\nLa scomparsa\n\nI tre erano appassionati di surf e sono stati visti l'ult", "hrv": "TIJELA troje turista prona\u0111ena u bunaru na sjeverozapadu Meksika imala su rane od metka na glavama, objavile su lokalne vlasti, a prenosi BBC.\n\nBra\u0107a iz Australije Jake i Callum Robinson (30 i 33) te njihov prijatelj, Amerikanac Jack Carter Rhoad (30) nestali su 27. travnja dok su bili na surfanju u Ensenadi, a tijela su prona\u0111ena u subotu.\n\nRo\u0111aci trojice mu\u0161karaca identificirali su sino\u0107 njihova tijela nakon \u0161to su otputovali u Meksiko kako bi pomogli u identificiranju.\n\nSlu\u017ebenici vjer"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Baja California"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Mexico"}}}, "categories": [{"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime", "wgt": 77}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Theft", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "news/Business", "label": "news/Business", "wgt": 53}], "articleCounts": {"eng": 114, "fra": 61, "spa": 53, "deu": 66, "por": 22, "zho": 24, "ita": 7, "hrv": 9}, "sentiment": -0.2156862745098039}
{"uri": "8113016880", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:18:42", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:18:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:18:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9490196108818054, "url": "https://chatnewstoday.ca/2024/05/05/3-bodies-in-mexican-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-trucks-tires/", "title": "3 bodies in Mexican well identified as Australian and American surfers killed for truck's tires", "body": "The well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nMEXICO CITY (AP) -- Thieves apparently killed two Australians and an American on a surfing trip to Mexico in order to steal their truck because they wanted the tires, authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors released grisly details of the slayings, but have not yet officially confirmed the identification of the bodies. They said family members of the victims are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep, some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed. If relatives can't identify the bodies, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\n\"The probability that it's them is very high,\" said chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, noting the corpses still appeared to be identifiable by sight. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nBut Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the case.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.", "source": {"uri": "chatnewstoday.ca", "dataType": "news", "title": "CHAT News Today"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-27", "textStart": 5867, "textEnd": 5875}], "sentiment": -0.2392156862745098, "wgt": 242, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8113015961", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:18:26", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:18:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:16:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.929411768913269, "url": "https://www.hjnews.com/world/3-bodies-in-mexican-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-trucks-tires/article_477f8fc2-7c44-5925-b461-070dd6349d40.html", "title": "3 bodies in Mexican well identified as Australian and American surfers killed for truck's tires", "body": "MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. {"uri": "8113015805", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:17:50", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:17:50Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:16:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9254902005195618, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/485913/3-bodies-in-Mexican-well-identified-as-Australian-and-American-surfers-killed-for-truck-s-tires", "title": "3 bodies in Mexican well identified as Australian and American surfers killed for truck's tires - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press Locals march to protest the disappearance of foreign surfers in Ensenada, Mexico, Sunday, May 5, 2024. Mexican authorities said Friday that three bodies were recovered in an area of Baja California near where two Australians and an American went missing last weekend during an apparent camping and surfing trip. (AP Photo/Karen Castaneda)\n\nMexican authorities said Sunday that relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said relatives from the two countries had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nTHIS IS A BREAKING NEWS UPDATE. AP's earlier story follows below.\n\nMEXICO CITY (AP) -- Thieves apparently killed two Australians and an American on a surfing trip to Mexico in order to steal their truck because they wanted the tires, authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors released grisly details of the slayings, but have not yet officially confirmed the identification of the bodies. They said family members of the victims are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep, some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed. If relatives can't identify the bodies, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\n\"The probability that it's them is very high,\" said chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, noting the corpses still appeared to be identifiable by sight. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nBut Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the case.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. {"uri": "8113013473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:15:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:15:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:13:34Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9098039269447327, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/05/05/world/three-bodies-mexican-well-identified-australian-american-surfers-killed-trucks-tires/", "title": "Three bodies in Mexican well identified as Australian and American surfers killed for truck's tires - The Boston Globe", "body": "Thieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston {"uri": "8113049657", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:04:27", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:04:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:04:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2928547-3-bodies-in-mexican-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-drug-money", "title": "3 Bodies in Mexican Well Identified as Australian and American Surfers Killed for Drug Money | Law-Order", "body": "Relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said Sunday.Baja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet 15 meters deep and recognized them as their loved ones.Thieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexicos Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires.\n\nRelatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend. Chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\" She said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\" But in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\" At the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\" Gabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\" \"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges. The third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8113071111", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:29:41", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:29:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:28:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.nzherald.co.nz/world/mexico-murders-three-bodies-in-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-tyres/EOFQZTV6LZDQ7K73MPS3XLQKIM/", "title": "Bodies in well identified as Australian and American surfers killed for tyres", "body": "Relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said today.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 5 metres deep and recognised them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tyres. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 6 kilometres from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorised the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tyres. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found last week along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in a weekend editorial that \"the reality is, the dangers of travelling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore\".\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room\".\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surfboards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamine. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the US Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The US State Department said it was aware of reports of a US citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. {"uri": "8113054905", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:11:01", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:11:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:09:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8901960849761963, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-3-bodies-in-mexican-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-trucks-tires-5943177.html", "title": "World News | 3 Bodies in Mexican Well Identified as Australian and American Surfers Killed for Truck's Tires | LatestLY", "body": "Mexico City, May 6 (AP) Relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nAlso Read | Jair Bolsonaro Hospitalised for Erysipelas: Former Brazil President in Hospital To Treat Skin Infection, Cancels His Meetings.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nAlso Read | Australia: Police Shot Dead Teenager Who Stabbed Man in Perth.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case. {"uri": "8113094884", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:56:34", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:56:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:54:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8823529481887817, "url": "https://www.newstalkzb.co.nz/news/world/mexico-murders-three-bodies-in-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-tyres/", "title": "Bodies in well identified as Australian and American surfers killed for tyres", "body": "Relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said today.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 5 metres deep and recognised them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tyres. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 6 kilometres from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nJake and Callum Robinson (left) were missing in Mexico along with their American friend, Jack Carter Rhoad but have now been identified by family.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorised the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tyres. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nMexico's police officers stand guard at the Ensenada station in Ensenada, Mexico. Photo / AP\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found last week along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in a weekend editorial that \"the reality is, the dangers of travelling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore\".\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room\".\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surfboards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamine. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nAustralian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson and an American friend Jack Carter Rhoad failed to show up for an Airbnb booked in the Pacific resort of Rosarito.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the US Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The US State Department said it was aware of reports of a US citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. They said family members of the victims are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep, some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed. If relatives can't identify the bodies, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\n\"The probability that it's them is very high,\" said chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, noting the corpses still appeared to be identifiable by sight. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nRELATED: 3 bodies found in search for US and Australian surfers who mysteriously vanished in Mexico\n\nBut Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the case.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. {"uri": "8113123074", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:25:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:25:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:24:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8627451062202454, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/05/06/world/australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-trucks-tires-in-mexico/1944933", "title": "Australian and American surfers killed for truck's tires in Mexico", "body": "MEXICO CITY: Relatives have identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed sympathy for the Robinson family. \"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said at a news conference Monday in the capital, Canberra.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the US Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The US State Department said it was aware of reports of a US citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Manila times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@manilatimes.net", "name": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Methamphetamine", "type": "wiki", "score": 1, "label": {"eng": "Methamphetamine"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kidnapping", "type": "wiki", "score": 1,
