"dmoz/Society/Crime", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime_and_Justice", "label": "dmoz/Society/Issues/Crime and Justice", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Murder", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "label": "dmoz/Society/Crime/Victims", "wgt": 100}, {"uri": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "label": "dmoz/Society/Death/Suicide", "wgt": 100}], "image": "https://img.resized.co/breaking--bodies-in-mexico-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers.jpg", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9541608", "eventUri": "eng-9541608", "location": null, "extractedDates": null, "sentiment": -0.207843137254902, "wgt": 216, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-345957647", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:54:15", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:54:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T15:43:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-05-05/3-bodies-in-mexican-well-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers-killed-for-trucks-tires", "title": "3 Bodies in Mexican Well Identified as Australian and American Surfers Killed for Truck's Tires", "body": "MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Relatives have identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tires. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed sympathy for the Robinson family. \"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said at a news conference Monday in the capital, Canberra.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved. This material may not be published, broadcast, rewritten or redistributed.", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": {"uri": "8113197632", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:40:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:40:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:39:09Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://todayheadline.co/mexican-authorities-say-thieves-killed-2-australians-american/", "title": "Mexican authorities say thieves killed 2 Australians, American", "body": "Baja California state prosecutors released grisly details of the slayings, but have not yet officially confirmed the identification of the bodies. They said family members of the victims are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThieves apparently dumped the bodies into a remote well about 50 feet deep, some four miles from where the foreigners were killed. If relatives can't identify the bodies, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\n\"The probability that it's them is very high,\" said chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nBut Andrade Ram\u00edrez described the moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe said the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents, and wanted to steal their tires.\n\n\"The attackers drove by in their vehicle,\" said Andrade Ram\u00edrez. \"They approached, with the intention of stealing their vehicle and taking the tires and other parts to put them on the older-model pickup they were driving.\n\n\"When they [the foreigners] came up and caught them, surely, they resisted,\" she said. \"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then others came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nThe assailants then apparently burned the foreigners' tents.\n\nThe thieves then went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surfboards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, some of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. On Friday, the office said the three had been arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if they might face more charges.\n\nAt least one of the suspects was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9541608", "eventUri": "eng-9541608", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-04-27", "textStart": 5052, "textEnd": 5060}], "sentiment": -0.3019607843137255, "wgt": 210, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-05-345964224", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:55:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:55:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T18:50:54Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.washingtontimes.com/news/2024/may/5/surfers-from-australians-and-america-killed-in-mex/", "title": "Surfers from Australian and America killed in Mexico by thieves over truck, authorities say", "body": "MEXICO CITY -- Thieves apparently killed two Australians and an American on a surfing trip to Mexico in order to steal their truck because they wanted the tires, authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors released grisly details of the slayings, but have not yet officially confirmed the identification of the bodies. They said family members of the victims are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep, some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed. If relatives can't identify the bodies, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\n\"The probability that it's them is very high,\" said chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, noting the corpses still appeared to be identifiable by sight. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nBut Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf - we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the case.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California - also known as the Sea of Cortez - from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.", "source": {"uri": "washingtontimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Washington Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some four miles from where the victims were killed and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the victims' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the tourists) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed sympathy for the Robinson family. \"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said at a news conference Monday in the capital, Canberra.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nSurfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nRobinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. {"uri": "8113030959", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:39:53", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:39:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:39:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/world-news/2024/05/06/three-bodies-in-mexico-identified-as-australian-and-american-surfers/", "title": "Three bodies in Mexico identified as Australian and American surfers", "body": "Relatives have positively identified three bodies found in a well as those of two Australian surfers and one American who went missing last weekend, Mexican authorities said on Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 15 metres deep and recognised them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tyres. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some four miles from where the foreigners were killed and also contained a fourth corpse that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nChief state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorised the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tyres. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted\".\n\nShe said that was when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with.\n\nShe said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards.\n\n\"It was almost impossible to find it,\" Ms Andrade Ramirez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tomas was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found on Thursday along the coast.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings.\n\nIn keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jesus Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas\", a slang word that means \"quesadillas\", or cheese tortillas. {"uri": "2024-05-345940817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:50:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:50:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-05T22:26:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.ntd.com/mexican-authorities-say-thieves-killed-2-australians-and-an-american-to-steal-their-truck_990776.html?utm_content=buffer67c4f&utm_medium=Social&utm_source=facebook&utm_campaign=ntdaus&fbclid=IwZXh0bgNhZW0CMTEAAR1_HJ6XkqPRMutnlo9xXatkgAAPBy1oI_YS5RHkLNGE8ylpkX7cpk6UhuU_aem_AZD8M4jzB0J_JMDIqeFpecNIkQhWIu2sJN2mivKHWhIljbkQH0_6_lUZQolIsBuj87sNs28pPn5oa9Zky7GF-zMi", "title": "Thieves Apparently Killed 2 Australians and American to Steal Their Truck, Mexican Authorities Say", "body": "MEXICO CITY -- Thieves apparently killed two Australians and an American on a surfing trip to Mexico in order to steal their truck because they wanted the tires, authorities said Sunday.\n\nBaja California state prosecutors released grisly details of the slayings, but have not yet officially confirmed the identification of the bodies. They said family members of the victims are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote well about 50 feet (15 meters) deep, some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed. If relatives can't identify the bodies, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\n\"The probability that it's them is very high,\" said chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, noting the corpses still appeared to be identifiable by sight. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nBut Ms. Andrade Ram\u00edrez described the moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe said the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents, and wanted to steal their tires.\n\n\"The attackers drove by in their vehicle,\" said Ms. Andrade Ram\u00edrez. \"They approached, with the intention of stealing their vehicle and taking the tires and other parts to put them on the older-model pickup they were driving.\n\n\"When they [the foreigners] came up and caught them, surely, they resisted,\" she said. \"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then others came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nThe assailants then apparently burned the foreigners' tents.\n\nThe thieves then went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Ms. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Ms. Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast. From their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nBut in a way, adventure was key to the victims' lifestyle.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram account contained the following slogan: \"If you're not living on the edge, you're taking up too much room.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Ms. Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Ms. Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, some of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. On Friday, the office said the three had been arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if they might face more charges.\n\nAt least one of the suspects was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas.\n\nLast week, the mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada.\n\nMs. Robinson said Callum was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the U.S. Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that. The U.S. State Department said it was aware of reports of a U.S. citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.", "source": {"uri": "ntd.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NTD"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tire", "type": "wiki", "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/bodies-found-dumped-mexican-well-070324018.html", "title": "Bodies found dumped in Mexican well belong to missing surfers", "body": "Mexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by their parents.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Ms Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 metres (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nSurfers shot by car thieves\n\nThree people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the US Federal Bureau of Investigation.\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer. {"uri": "8113074648", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:33:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:33:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:32:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://7news.com.au/news/bodies-found-in-well-in-mexico-confirmed-as-missing-australian-surfers-callum-and-jake-robinson-and-their-us-friend-carter-rhoad-c-14563912", "title": "Dead bodies confirmed as missing Australian surfers", "body": "The brothers were travelling in Mexico's Baja California state when they disappeared just over a week ago.\n\nTwo Australians and an American were killed by thieves on a surfing trip to Mexico in order to steal their truck, particularly because they wanted the tyres, authorities say.\n\nThree dead bodies found in a well this week have now been identified by family as the missing tourists: Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30.\n\nThe Baja California Attorney-General's Office confirmed their identification on Sunday, after a regional official earlier revealed their parents had arrived in the country.\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote, 15m well. If relatives can't identify them, further tests will be conducted. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThe three men went missing last weekend during a camping and surfing trip, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada.\n\nBut Andrade Ramirez described the moments of terror that ended their trip.\n\nShe said the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents, and wanted to steal their tyres.\n\n\"Surely, they resisted,\" she said of the victims, and the thieves shot them to death.\n\nThe thieves then went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and dumped their bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with.\n\nShe said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of their thefts.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ramirez said.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tomas was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast.\n\nFrom their last photo posts, the trip looked perfect. But even experienced local expats are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial on Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of travelling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore\".\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case. On Friday, the office said the three had been arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if they might face more charges.\n\nAt least one of the suspects was believed to have directly participated in the killings.\n\nLast week, the missing Australians' mother, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page an appeal for help in finding her sons. Robinson said Callum and Jake had not been heard from since April 27. They had booked accommodations in the nearby city of Rosarito.\n\nRobinson said one of her sons, Callum, was diabetic. She also mentioned that the American who was with them was named Jack Carter Rhoad, but the US Embassy in Mexico City did not immediately confirm that.\n\nThe US State Department said it was aware of reports of a US citizen missing in Baja, but gave no further details.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. {"uri": "8113025033", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:30:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:30:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:30:13Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41389156.html", "title": "Three bodies in Mexico identified as Australian and American surfers", "body": "Baja California state prosecutors said the relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from a remote well about 15 metres deep and recognised them as their loved ones.\n\nThieves apparently killed the three, who were on a surfing trip to Mexico's Baja peninsula, to steal their truck because they wanted the tyres. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some four miles from where the foreigners were killed and also contained a fourth corpse that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos of waves and isolated beaches on social media before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorised the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tyres. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted\".\n\nShe said that was when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with.\n\nShe said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Ms Andrade Ramirez said.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards.\n\n\"It was almost impossible to find it,\" Ms Andrade Ramirez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tomas was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found on Thursday along the coast.\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the killings, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings.\n\nIn keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jesus Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas\", a slang word that means \"quesadillas\", or cheese tortillas. "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.fijitimes.com.fj/parents-identify-bodies-of-u-s-australian-tourists-missing-in-mexico/", "title": "Parents identify bodies of U.S., Australian tourists missing in Mexico", "body": "MEXICO CITY (Reuters) -Mexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by parents.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nSHOT BY CAR THIEVES\n\nThree people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer. {"uri": "8113128394", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "04:32:14", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T04:32:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T04:31:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2024/5/6/bodies-of-murdered-australian-us-surfers-identified-in-mexico", "title": "Bodies of murdered Australian, US surfers identified in Mexico", "body": "The three men were killed during a camping and surfing trip along Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nMexican authorities have confirmed the deaths of an American and two Australians who went missing in northern Mexico last week after the tourists' parents identified their bodies.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson as well as their friend, United States citizen Carter Rhoad, were found at the bottom of a well in the state of Baja California after a days-long search.\n\nAll three were in their early 30s and had been shot in the head.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement from the state prosecutor's office said.\n\nThe three men went missing while on a surfing holiday near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nThey are believed to have been killed after resisting an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said at a news conference.\n\nThe vehicle, which had been set on fire, was found nearby.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed sympathy for the Robinson family. \"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the case.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a well about 50 feet (15 metres) deep in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the US's Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California, one of Mexico's most violent states because of organised crime gangs, is also known for its inviting beaches and the Ensenada area is considered among its safer parts.\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, it took weeks, months, or even years for action to be taken.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered on Sunday in Ensenada to pay their respects to the surfers and voice their anger over the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters.\n\nMany marched with city of Ensenada, when they went missing on April 27.\n\nMexican authorities assisted by the the US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) found their bodies in a well in the town of Santo Tomas on Friday.\n\nTheir parents traveled to Mexico to officially confirm the remains were those of their sons.\n\nMexican prosecutors said their remains all had bullet wounds to the heads.\n\nThey were found found dead in Mexican well were shot in the headOur Foreign StaffMay 6, 2024 at 12:33 PM\n\nMexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by their parents.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Ms Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 metres (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nSurfers shot by car thieves\n\nThree people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the US Federal Bureau of Investigation.\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer. The US State Department advises Americans to reconsider travel to the state due to crime and kidnapping.\n\nBroaden your horizons with award-winning British journalism. which had been burned - was found nearby.\n\nREAD | Mexican mob kills woman suspected of murdering 8-year-old girl\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to Mexican prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition\".\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 45km southeast of Ensenada.\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30.\n\nIt named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nThe friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems, Andrade said.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: Enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nAt 1.93m tall, Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organised crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths\".\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nCriminal violence in Mexico has claimed 450 000 lives and led to more than 100 000 disappearances {"uri": "2024-05-346721426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:16:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:16:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/05/07/world/americas-emea/bodies-of-slain-surfers-identified-in-mexico/1944933", "title": "Bodies of slain surfers identified in Mexico", "body": "TIJUANA, Mexico: Relatives on Sunday identified the bodies of two Australians and an American shot dead in a suspected robbery in Mexico, authorities said, marking a tragic end to the search for the missing surfers.\n\nThe corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, officials in crime-hit Baja California state said, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad, who were on a surf trip to Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nSIGN OF SYMPATHY A man raises a surfboard that reads 'Australia we are with you' next to members of the surfing community who are protesting against insecurity after three surfers -- two Australians, one American -- went missing last week, in the city of Ensenada, Baja California state, northwestern Mexico on Sunday, May 5, 2024. AFP PHOTO\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pickup truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade told a news conference.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the surfers.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\"\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them,\" he said.\n\nMexico's Foreign Minister Alicia Barcena expressed her condolences in a statement, saying her office \"maintained a constant and direct dialogue with the Australian Ambassador to Mexico Rachel Elizabeth Moseley and her team to support the efforts of the diplomatic mission.\"\n\nAdvertisement\n\nTwo men and one woman have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, Mexican prosecutors said.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was not connected to the others, officials said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nAgence France-Presse (AFP) journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Tomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of the city of Ensenada.\n\n'Tragic loss'\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\nAdvertisement\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday, 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nThe friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems, Andrade said.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93-meter) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in the western Australian city of Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nCriminal violence in Mexico has claimed 450,000 lives and led to more than 100,000 disappearances since the end of {"uri": "8114070459", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "15:42:18", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T15:42:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T15:41:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.newsamericasnow.com/bodies-of-murdered-australian-us-surfers-identified-in-mexico/", "title": "Positive Caribbean and Latin America News: Daily Updates from News Americas", "body": "The content originally appeared on: Latin America News - Aljazeera\n\nMexican authorities have confirmed the deaths of an American and two Australians who went missing in northern Mexico last week after the tourists' parents identified their bodies.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson as well as their friend, United States citizen Carter Rhoad, were found at the bottom of a well in the state of Baja California after a days-long search.\n\nAll three were in their early 30s and had been shot in the head.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement from the state prosecutor's office said.\n\nThe three men went missing while on a surfing holiday near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nThey are believed to have been killed after resisting an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said at a news conference.\n\nThe vehicle, which had been set on fire, was found nearby.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed sympathy for the Robinson family. \"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been arrested on suspicion of involvement in the case.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a well about 50 feet (15 metres) deep in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the US's Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California, one of Mexico's most violent states because of organised crime gangs, is also known for its inviting beaches and the Ensenada area is considered among its safer parts.\n\nAt the news conference, Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who expressed approval that such a massive and rapid search was mounted for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people disappear in the area, it took weeks, months, or even years for action to be taken.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name. \"Every investigation is different,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nAs if to underscore that point, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered on Sunday in Ensenada to pay their respects to the surfers and voice their anger over the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters.\n\nMany marched with {"uri": "2024-05-346046762", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:12:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:12:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:32:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.channelstv.com/2024/05/06/bodies-of-murdered-australian-us-surfers-identified-in-mexico/", "title": "Bodies Of Murdered Australian, US Surfers Identified In Mexico", "body": "Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\nRelatives on Sunday identified the bodies of two Australians and an American shot dead in a suspected robbery in Mexico, authorities said, marking a tragic end to the search for the missing surfers.\n\nThe corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad, who were on a surf trip to Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them,\" he said.\n\nMexico's foreign minister Alicia Barcena expressed her condolences in a statement, saying that her office \"maintained a constant and direct dialogue with the Australian Ambassador to Mexico, Rachel Elizabeth Moseley, and her team, to support the efforts of the diplomatic mission.\"\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to Mexican prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\n- 'Tragic loss' -\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nThe friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems, Andrade said.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nCriminal violence in Mexico has claimed 450,000 lives and led to more than 100,000 disappearances since the end of 2006, when the government launched a controversial anti-drug strategy Visit image gallery to purchase the image.\n\nMexican authorities have confirmed the two Australians and one American who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by parents.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nThree people have so far been The three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nMexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by parents. The bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast. Baja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added. On Saturday, Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head. Australian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference. \"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nSHOT BY CAR THIEVES Three people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well. The three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer.
