UrduPoint", "body": "The corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter, who were on a surf trip to Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them,\" the senior government minister said.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to Mexican prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and {"uri": "8114357309", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:38:38", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:38:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:37:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7098039388656616, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/crime/american-australian-surfers-mexico-death-b2540316.html", "title": "Motive revealed in killing of two Australian and American surfers in Mexico", "body": "Two Australians and one American were killed while on a surfing trip in Mexico's Baja peninsula after thieves targeted the group of friends for their truck tires, Mexican authorities have revealed.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Jake, 30, and Callum Robinson, 33, and their friend Jack Carter Rhoad, 30, from San Diego, California, were dumped down a well in a remote area around four miles from where they were shot in the head.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said on Sunday that she believed the killers drove by and saw the surfers' pickup truck and tents, and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted,\" she added.\n\nThe prosecutor said that the relatives had viewed the bodies recovered from a remote well about 50 feet deep, and recognized them as their loved ones.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case.\n\nHere's everything we know so far.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast, south of the city of Ensenada. They had been posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches before they went missing on 27 April.\n\nThe mother of the missing Australians, Debra Robinson, had posted on a local community Facebook page, appealing for help in finding her sons after she had not heard from them. The friends had booked accommodation in the city of Rosarito, not far from Ensenada, but never showed up.\n\nProsecutor Andrade Ram\u00edrez said on Sunday that the site where the bodies were discovered, near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s, was a remote seaside area. Their missing tents and truck were found on Thursday along the coast.\n\n\"When they tried to get the vehicles, the victims opposed the robbery,\" she said. \"The robbers were armed with a firearm and then apparently shot the victims.\"\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and dumped the bodies into a well, they apparently were familiar with, and covered the hole with boards.\n\n\"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Ms Andrade Ram\u00edrez said. She aded that it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nA fourth body was found with the young men. It is believed to be the remains of a rancher who owned the property and went missing two weeks earlier. His death is not believed to be linked to the case, authorities said.\n\nMs Andrade Ram\u00edrez said investigators were not ruling out the possibility that the same suspects dumped the fourth body in the well as part of a previous crime.\n\nInvestigators announced that three Mexican citizens had been charged with a crime equivalent to kidnapping in connection with the tourists' disappearance.\n\nThey are Jes\u00fas Gerardo, whose alias is \"el Kekas\" is slang word that means \"quesadillas\"; his partner Ari Gisel Garc\u00eda Cota; and Jes\u00fas' brother, Cristian Alejandro Garcia. They have not been charged with murder.\n\nProsecutors said they were questioning three people in connection with the killings. Two of the suspects were also caught with methamphetamines.\n\nIn 2015, two Australian surfers, Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas, were killed in western Sinaloa state, across the Gulf of California -- also known as the Sea of Cortez -- from the Baja peninsula. Authorities said they were victims of highway bandits. Three suspects were arrested in that case.\n\nFrom the surfers' last social media posts, their trip looked picture perfect.\n\nBut even experienced local expatriates are questioning whether it is safe to camp along the largely deserted coast anymore, The Associated Press reported.\n\nThe moderator of the local Talk Baja internet forum, who has lived in the area for almost two decades, wrote in an editorial on Saturday that \"the reality is, the dangers of traveling to and camping in remote areas are outweighing the benefits anymore.\"\n\nRandy Dible, a San Diego photographer, and friend of Callum Robinson's recalled how he told him about his favorite surfing spot in Baja, La Bocana, and wrote out directions on a napkin, according to the New York Post.\n\nMr Dible said he almost tagged along on the trip but had to cancel when a last-minute job came in, Mr Dible toldThe Australian.\n\n\"I told him about this place because I'd been traveling down there all over that country for 30 years so I know it like the back of my hand and I knew just where to go,\" the friend said. \"And he was murdered in the exact same spot.\"\n\nHe said that he now regrets ever mentioning the surfing spot to Callum. \"I wish I'd never met up with him that day, I feel really bad. I feel guilty. It's just starting to hit home.\"\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed sympathy for the Robinson family.\n\n\"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said at a news conference on Monday in the capital Canberra.\n\nJack Carter Rhoad, the American slain in Mexico, was just months away from marrying his fianc\u00e9e, Natalie Wiertz, when he joined the two Australian brothers for the surfing trip.\n\nA photo on Rhoad's Facebook page shows the moment the couple got engaged. They were set to get married on 17 August in Ohio, according to their wedding website.\n\nIn the wake of the murders, the couple's friend, Aubrey Byers, created a GoFundMe page for two purposes, she wrote.\n\n\"The first is to rally support for Natalie during this unimaginably difficult time and provide essentials such as housing, food, transportation, and more,\" the friend wrote.\n\n\"The second is to honor Carter by raising money for scholarships and donations he felt passionate about. No donation is too small, and every contribution is deeply appreciated.\"\n\nCallum Robinson's girlfriend, Emily Horwath, who lives in San Diego, revealed that her \"heart is shattered into a million pieces\" after his death.\n\n\"My heart is shattered into a million pieces,\" she wrote on Instagram alongside a photo of her and Mr Robinson hugging.\n\n\"You are one of one. I will love you forever,\" she captioned another photo.\n\nA separate GoFundMe is dedicated to the Australian brothers.\n\n\"In the wake of the heartbreaking loss of Callum Robinson and Jake Robinson, our hearts ache with grief for their families, friends, and community. Their presence brought immeasurable joy, love, and kindness to those around them, leaving a mark on our lives,\" it reads.\n\n\"In honor of their memory and the support of their families, we've created this GoFundMe page to rally around Martin and Debra Robinson during this unimaginably difficult time. Your generosity will assist with essentials such as housing, food, transportation, and more. No donation is too small, and every contribution is deeply appreciated.\"\n\nThe brothers had attended the Coachella music festival before heading to Mexico to surf.\n\n\"Jake is such a gentle soul and would want no harm,\" his parents said in a statement. \"Our only comfort right now is that they were together doing something they passionately love.\n\n\"We ask people to keep them in their thoughts and prayers and to continue to respect our privacy at this distressing time.\"\n\nAt the news conference, Ms Andrade Ram\u00edrez was questioned by one reporter who commended the large and widespread search for the foreigners, but asked why, when local people often disappear in the area, little is often done for weeks, months, or years.\n\n\"Do you have to be a foreigner in Baja California in order for there to be an investigation if something happens to you?' asked the reporter, who did not identify herself by name, according to the Associated Press.\n\n\"Every investigation is different,\" Ms Andrade Ram\u00edrez replied.\n\nDozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters.\n\n\"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration.\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer who attended the protest, said she came \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost.\" Ms Acosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone,\" Ms Acosta said. \"But we never do that, because of the situation. We always have to go accompanied.\"\n\n\"I think that what happened to them is just an example of the lack of safety in this state,\" she said.\n\nA woman held up a sign that read: \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nSurfers later led a \"paddle-out\" ceremony where they formed a circle on their boards in the ocean to pay their respects to the dead.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "2024-05-346627607", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:47:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:47:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:05:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.kadn.com/news/world/bodies-found-in-mexico-confirmed-as-those-of-missing-american-and-australian-tourists/article_73d64b6c-d2df-5d22-9314-bcfcf45d5b08.html", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists", "body": "Three bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said.\n\n(CNN) -- Three bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\n'Infectious spirit'\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\n'We need security'\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis is a breaking news story and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Discovery Company. {"uri": "8113175428", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:19:31", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:19:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:18:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7058823704719543, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/mexican-authorities-reveal-bizarre-reason-011912694.html", "title": "Mexican authorities reveal bizarre reason they believe Australians, American were murdered on surfing vacation", "body": "Mexican authorities say two Australians and an American were killed on a surfing trip because thieves wanted the tires from their truck. Relatives of those killed confirmed their identities on Sunday, the Associated Press reported.\n\nThe latest details in the case come after a fourth body was discovered during a search for the missing men in Baja California. State prosecutors have not officially confirmed the identities of the missing men, but have said the victims' family members are viewing the bodies to see if they can be identified by sight.\n\nThe corpses were found decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote well about 50 feet deep, some four miles from where the men were killed, authorities said. The well also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said the probability that the corpses belong to the missing men is \"very high,\" noting that they still appeared to be identifiable by sight. \"If they say that they are not completely certain that it is their relative, we would then have to carry out genetic testing.\"\n\nUTAH HUNTER FINDS SKELETAL REMAINS OF MAN MISSING SINCE 2019 IN REMOTE MOUNTAINS\n\nThe three men, brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad, were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada when they went missing last weekend.\n\nREAD ON THE FOX NEWS APP\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. But \"when [the foreigners] came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nShe said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a familiar well. She said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nMAN CONVICTED OF KIDNAPPING GIRLFRIEND, SUFFOCATING HER IN NEVADA DESERT\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tom\u00e1s was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast.\n\nOn Sunday, dozens of mourners, surfers and demonstrators gathered in a main plaza in Ensenada, the nearest city, to voice their anger and sadness at the deaths.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one placard carried by protesters. \"Australia, we are with you,\" one man scrawled on one of the half-dozen surf boards at the demonstration. A woman held up a sign that read \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nBaja California prosecutors had said they were questioning three people in the case, two of them because they were caught with methamphetamines. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the case.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third suspect was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" or cheese tortillas.\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record, and that more people may have been involved.\n\nThe Associated Press contributed to this report.", "source": {"uri": "yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, Officials had initially been waiting for DNA testing to confirm the remains found belonged to the surfers, but the victims' relatives were able to identify the bodies, Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe Australian victims were identified by the Mexican government as Jake and Callum Robinson and the American was identified as Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nThe FBI confirmed three bodies were found on Friday. Mexican officials said the bodies were found in a well that's more than 50 feet deep. A fourth body was found in the well, but authorities said they don't believe the final body is related to the missing surfers. The bodies were found in the town of Santa Tomas in the Mexican state of Baja California.\n\nThe missing Australians and their American friend were last seen in late April, officials said. Investigators examined the area where the surfers had been camping in Mexico. They found tent poles, a cartridge casing, plastic gallon bottles, blood stains and drag marks.\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez said it's believed the victims were attacked for their truck. She said the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents, and wanted to steal their tires.\n\n\"The attackers drove by in their vehicle,\" said Andrade Ram\u00edrez. \"They approached, with the intention of stealing their vehicle and taking the tires and other parts to put them on the older-model pickup they were driving.\n\n\"When they (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted,\" she said. \"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then others came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nThe assailants then apparently burned the foreigners' tents.\n\nJes\u00fas Gerardo, an alleged suspect in the case, is currently in prison while two others are in preventive detention as officials investigate the case further, authorities said. Jes\u00fas Gerardo, whose alias is \"el Kekas,\" has a criminal record.\n\nAuthorities have not ruled out the other two, a man and a woman who have not been identified, could be \"directly or indirectly related to this case,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nThe Pacific coast state of Baja California is a popular tourist destination that is also plagued by cartel violence. The U.S. State Department warns Americans should reconsider travel to the region because of crime and kidnapping.\n\nOn Wednesday, the Australians' mother, Debra Robinson, posted on a local community Facebook page an appeal for help finding her sons. {"uri": "2024-05-345958731", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:54:07", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:54:07Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:05:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/05/05/americas/mexico-surfer-bodies-identified-intl-hnk/index.html", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists", "body": "Hear what Mexican official says about possible motive for death of the three surfers\n\nCNN --\n\nThree bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\n'Infectious spirit'\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nThe bodies of Callum and Jake Robinson were found in a well in Baja California, Mexico. Callum Robinson/Instagram\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\nPhotos of the American and Australian surfers on a beach in Ensenada, Mexico on May 5, 2024. Karen Castaneda/AP\n\n'We need security'\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nA demonstrator holds photos of the surfers during a protest in Ensenada, Mexico, on May 5, 2024. Karen Castaneda/AP\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis is a breaking news story and will be updated.", "source": {"uri": "cnn.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "CNN"}, "authors": [{"uri": of an American and two Australian surfers presumed to have been killed in northern Mexico have arrived in the country and will try to identify the dead bodies believed to be their children, a Mexican Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30.\n\nBut those tests are taking some time and Baja California's state Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade said the parents are currently filling out paperwork to see if the bodies can be \"physically identified, that is to say, in plain sight.\"\n\nIf the parents are able to identify the bodies, it would void the need for DNA tests, Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said there was a \"high grade of probability\" that the three bodies found earlier in the week belonged to the surfers.\n\nAndrade {"uri": "8113048704", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:03:23", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:03:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:02:55Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.swissinfo.ch/eng/parents-identify-bodies-of-u.s.,-australian-tourists-missing-in-mexico/76992008", "title": "Parents identify bodies of U.S., Australian tourists missing in Mexico", "body": "MEXICO CITY (Reuters) - Mexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by parents.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nThree people have so far been arrested, officials say. {"uri": "8113643387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:58:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:58:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:57:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://keyt.com/news/national-world/cnn-world/2024/05/05/bodies-found-in-mexico-confirmed-as-those-of-missing-american-and-australian-tourists-2/", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists", "body": "(CNN) -- Three bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional information.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. HowAfrica Latest news, views, gossip, photos and video", "body": "Relatives recognized the remains of two Australians and an American who were shot dead in a suspected robbery in Mexico on Sunday, bringing the search for the three surfers to a terrible end.\n\nOfficials in crime-hit Baja California state discovered three bodies with bullet wounds to their heads, indicating an execution-style slaying.\n\nThe discovery confirmed the darkest concerns of the families and friends of Callum and Jake Robinson, Australian brothers, and Jack Carter Rhoad, an American buddy, who were on a surf trip along Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nAt a press conference, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade stated that the three was thought to have been slain while attempting to steal their pickup truck.\n\nThe burned-out automobile was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later stated that the bodies were officially identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them,\" he said.\n\nMexico's foreign minister, Alicia Barcena, issued a statement expressing her condolences, noting that her office \"maintained a constant and direct dialogue with the Australian Ambassador to Mexico, Rachel Elizabeth Moseley, and her team, to support the efforts of the diplomatic mission.\"\n\nMexican prosecutors have apprehended three individuals, two males and one woman, on suspicion of being involved in the case.\n\nOne of those apprehended has a history of violence, drug dealing, and robbery, officials added.\n\nInvestigators had stated that the bodies were retrieved from a cliff-top shaft in a \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse discovered at the site had been there longer and was unrelated to the others, officials added.\n\nOn Friday, AFP photographers witnessed authorities using a pulley system to rescue the mud-covered bodies from the pit near the hamlet of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\n'Tragic loss'\n\nDebra Robinson, the Australian brothers' mother, had posted an alert on a Facebook page for Baja California vacationers few days ago, after the young men became silent.\n\n\"I am reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They haven't contacted us since Saturday, April 27th,\" she stated, attaching a poster from friends desperate for information on their location.\n\nA missing notice on social media stated that Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It identified their companion as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nAndrade stated that the companions had previously visited Mexico without any concerns.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram feed featured multiple photographs from the trio's Mexico trip, including them drinking beers with their feet up in a bar, relaxing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, and looking out at the surf.\n\nCallum, who stands six feet four (1.93 meters), played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which published a comment on its website stating that the lacrosse community was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nAustralian media said that Jake Robinson worked as a doctor in Perth.\n\nBaja California is famed for its appealing beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, thanks to its closeness to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states due to organized crime organizations, while cartel violence rarely affects foreign visitors.\n\nOn Sunday, dozens of surfers protested in Ensenada, writing slogans on their boards that included \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe scenario is similar to that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their remains burned while vacationing in the northern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nSince the end of 2006, when the government initiated a contentious anti-drug strategy using the military, criminal violence in Mexico has killed {"uri": "2024-05-346580172", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "14:05:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T14:05:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:05:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.channel3000.com/news/bodies-found-in-mexico-confirmed-as-those-of-missing-american-and-australian-tourists/article_0c3a6f83-71e6-5488-bd2e-5be9511be94f.html", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists", "body": "(CNN) -- Three bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\n'Infectious spirit'\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\n'We need security'\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional information.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. UrduPoint", "body": "The corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of holidaying Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe bodies \"all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile,\" Andrade said, adding that the friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed in a statement that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake, and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe latest case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.", "source": {"uri": "urdupoint.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "UrduPoint"}, {"uri": "8114378029", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "19:59:09", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T19:59:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T19:58:31Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6784313917160034, "url": "https://mexiconewsdaily.com/news/missing-tourists-bodies-identified-ensenada-baja-california/", "title": "Missing tourists' bodies identified in Ensenada; surfers pay tribute and demand safety", "body": "Three bodies found south of the city of Ensenada last week have been identified as those of two Australian brothers and another man from the United States who went missing during a surfing and camping trip to Baja California in late April.\n\nThe Baja California Attorney General's Office (FGE) said in a statement that three bodies found in a 15-meter-deep well on a clifftop in the area known as La Bocana were confirmed to be those of Callum and Jake Robinson, two brothers from the Western Australian city of Perth, and Jack Carter Rhoad of San Diego.\n\nThe FGE said that the families of the victims identified the bodies and that genetic tests weren't required.\n\nA fourth male body in an advanced state of decomposition was found in the same well. That body has not been identified and was apparently dumped in the well sometime before the three foreign tourists went missing.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez told a press conference on Sunday that the bodies identified as those of the three foreign tourists all had gunshot wounds to the head.\n\nAuthorities believe that the alleged killer or killers drove past the men's campsite, saw their tents and pickup truck and wanted to steal the vehicle for its tires and other parts.\n\n\"Surely they resisted,\" Andrade said, adding that it is believed that the men were subsequently shot and killed.\n\nShe noted that a range of evidence was found at the campsite, including a single bullet casing, blood stains, drag marks, tent poles and plastic bottles.\n\n\"This makes us think they were attacked and since then we doubted we'd find them alive,\" Andrade said.\n\nThe attorney general said that the aggressors disposed of the bodies in a well in a hard-to-get-to location some six to eight kilometers from the campsite.\n\n\"This is what happened,\" Andrade said, adding that the men weren't targeted because they were tourists but because they had a vehicle the aggressors wanted to steal.\n\n\"[The killers] probably didn't know the origin of these people,\" she said, although the pickup truck -- which was found burnt out on a ranch in nearby Santo Tom\u00e1s -- had license plates from the state of California.\n\nAndrade said that the parents of the victims understood that their sons, all aged in their early 30s, had gone into an \"inhospitable\" area where there was no way of calling for help.\n\nAuthorities have arrested two men and one woman in connection with the disappearance and alleged murder of Callum and Jake Robinson and Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nAccording to media reports, they are Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garc\u00eda Cota, his brother Cristian Alejandro Garc\u00eda Cota and Ari Gisel, who has been identified as Jes\u00fas Garc\u00eda's girlfriend. The woman was detained in possession of one of the deceased men's cell phones.\n\nAndrade said Sunday that Jes\u00fas Garc\u00eda Cota, known as \"El Kekas\" (a colloquial term for quesadillas), was detained on kidnapping charges. The attorney general said that he has a criminal record.\n\nShe noted that the other two suspects are in preventive detention on drug possession charges and said they could be directly or indirectly related to the alleged murder of the three foreign tourists.\n\n\"El Kekas\" had previously been convicted of extortion and vehicle theft in the municipality of Ensenada.\n\nAndrade said that the three people detained do not belong to a criminal group that \"controls\" territory in Ensenada.\n\nBaja California Governor Marina del Pilar called on \"the state's judicial power\" to apply the law with \"complete rigor against those responsible for these terrible events.\"\n\n\"Baja California is and will continue being a state with a safe tourism [experience] for the thousands of people who visit us from the rest of the country and the world,\" the governor added in a post on X.\n\nBaja California was Mexico's third most violent state last year in terms of total homicides, but killings of foreign tourists are rare.\n\nJake Robinson, a doctor, traveled to the United States in April to visit his brother Callum, who lived in San Diego and played professional lacrosse in the U.S.\n\nThey attended the Coachella music festival in California before traveling to Baja California with Rhoad, who lived in San Diego and worked as a director at the company ITCO Solutions, according to his LinkedIn page.\n\n\"I love people. I'm lucky to have found a 'job' that fuels my passion for problem-solving by connecting the right people with the right companies,\" Rhoad wrote on his LinkedIn page.\n\nJake Robinson had worked in regional hospitals around Australia and was to take up a new position in the city of Geelong on his return, according to his parents.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" the men's parents said in a statement.\n\n\"... Our only comfort right now is that they were together doing something they passionately love,\" said Martin and Debra Robinson, who traveled to Baja California from Perth to identify their sons and meet with authorities.\n\nDebra Robinson had posted in the Talk Baja Facebook group to seek assistance locating Callum and Jake last week.\n\n\"They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April. They are traveling with another friend, an American citizen. They were due to book into an Airbnb in Rosarito after their camping weekend, but they did not show up,\" she wrote last Wednesday.\n\nIn a statement \"on behalf of Mexico,\" the Foreign Affairs Ministry (SRE) expressed its condolences \"for the tragic deaths of Australian citizens Jake and Callum Robinson and U.S. citizen Jack Carter Rhoad, who were vacationing in Baja California.\"\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry sympathizes with the families of the victims of this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome. Since their disappearance was reported, the Foreign Affairs Ministry has been in constant, direct contact with the Australian Ambassador to Mexico, Rachel Elizabeth Moseley, and her team to support their efforts,\" the SRE said.\n\n\"On the instructions of Foreign Secretary Alicia B\u00e1rcena Ibarra, Mexico's Ambassador to Australia, Ernesto C\u00e9spedes Oropeza, traveled to Baja California to provide consular assistance to the Australian embassy staff and to express Mexico's solidarity with the families of the youths,\" the ministry added.\n\nThe Baja California Surfing Association organized a \"march against insecurity\" at which surfers and others condemned the crime against the tourists from Australia and the United States and demanded security on the state's beaches.\n\nSurfers also participated in a \"paddle out\" tribute to the slain foreigners, who had enjoyed the waves off the Baja peninsula before their violent deaths.\n\n\"We're really, really sorry this happened. As local surfers from Baja California we're shaken to the core,\" Gino Passalacqua, vice president of the Baja Surf Club, told the Australian Broadcasting Corporation.", "source": {"uri": CITY - The parents of an American and two Australian surfers presumed to have been killed in northern Mexico have arrived in the country and will try to identify the dead bodies believed to be their children, a Mexican regional official said on Sunday.\n\nAuthorities in the Baja California state are conducting forensic tests on three corpses they found in a well this week and which they believe to be Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30.\n\nBut those tests are taking some time and Baja California's state Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade said the parents are currently filling out paperwork to see if the bodies can be \"physically identified, that is to say, in plain sight.\"\n\nALSO READ: Dead bodies in Mexico most probably are missing US, Australian surfers\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast\n\nIf the parents are able to identify the bodies, it would void the need for DNA tests, Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the US-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said there was a \"high grade of probability\" that the three bodies found earlier in the week belonged to the surfers.\n\nAndrade said that while the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters deep, \"some physical descriptions give us that high probability\".\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the US Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California is one of State Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nMexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by parents. The bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast. Baja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added. Three people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well. The three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer. {"uri": "2024-05-346242686", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:04:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:04:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T08:03:08Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.aol.com/news/bodies-found-mexico-confirmed-those-032221556.html", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists", "body": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian touristsKathleen Magramo and Karol Suarez, CNNMay 6, 2024 at 10:03 AM\n\nThree bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\n'Infectious spirit'\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\n'We need security'\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis story has been updated with additional information.\n\nCNN's Jose Alvarez, Sandi Sidhu, Fidel Gutierrez, David Shortell, Michael Rios and Chris Identified In Mexico", "body": "The corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck.\n\nTijuana, Mexico:\n\nRelatives on Sunday identified the bodies of two Australians and an American shot dead in a suspected robbery in Mexico, authorities said, marking a tragic end to the search for the missing surfers.\n\nThe corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter, who were on a surf trip to Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them,\" the senior government minister said.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to Mexican prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\n'Tragic loss'\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nThe friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems, Andrade said.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November {"uri": "2024-05-346069521", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:16:37", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:16:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:56:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6705882549285889, "url": "https://www.aol.com/bodies-found-mexico-confirmed-those-032221556.html", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists", "body": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian touristsKathleen Magramo and Karol Suarez, CNNMay 6, 2024 at 7:56 AM\n\nThree bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\n'Infectious spirit'\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\n'We need security'\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis is a breaking news story and will be updated.\n\nFor more CNN news and newsletters create an account at CNN.com", "source": {"uri": "aol.com",
