"sim": 0.658823549747467, "url": "https://thesun.my/world/bodies-identified-as-australian-us-surfers-murdered-in-mexico-JF12421109", "title": "Bodies identified as Australian, US surfers murdered in Mexico", "body": "TIJUANA, MEXICO: Three bodies were identified by relatives Sunday as those of two Australians and an American shot dead during a suspected botched robbery during a surfing trip to Mexico, authorities said.\n\nThe corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of holidaying Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe bodies \"all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile,\" Andrade said, adding that the friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed in a statement that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\n- 'Tragic loss' -\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake, and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe latest case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nCriminal violence in Mexico has claimed 450,000 lives and led to more than UrduPoint", "body": "Tijuana, (APP - UrduPoint / Pakistan Point News - 6th May, 2024) Relatives of two Australians and an American who disappeared on a surfing trip arrived in Mexico Sunday to identify their presumed bodies, which were found with gunshot wounds to the head, authorities said.\n\nBrothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their friend Jack Carter, were believed to have been killed during a botched theft of their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nBodies presumed to belong to the three men \"all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile,\" Andrade said, adding that the trio had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies, which were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in the crime-hit northwestern state of Baja California, were very likely those of the missing tourists.\n\nThe remains were in an \"advanced state of decomposition,\" Andrade said.\n\nBut \"given their clothing and certain characteristics such as long hair and specific physical descriptions, we have high probability,\" that the bodies are those of the three missing men, she said.\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. {"uri": "8113276080", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "06:50:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T06:50:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:45:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://kion546.com/news/national-world/cnn-world/2024/05/05/bodies-found-in-mexico-confirmed-as-those-of-missing-american-and-australian-tourists-2/", "title": "Bodies found in Mexico confirmed as those of missing American and Australian tourists - KION546", "body": "(CNN) -- Three bodies found dumped in a well with gunshot wounds to the head have been confirmed as missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities said Sunday.\n\nRelatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson identified their bodies without having to perform genetic tests, the Baja California Attorney General's office said in a statement on Sunday.\n\nThree Mexican citizens previously questioned in relation to their disappearance have been arrested on suspicion of kidnapping, the attorney general's office said. One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\nThe confirmation of the surfers' deaths is heartbreaking news for desperate relatives who had flown to Mexico hoping for better news - and for their friends back home.\n\nJake Robinson, a 30-year-old doctor, had left Australia about two weeks ago for \"a trip of a lifetime\" with his brother, his parents previously told CNN affiliate Seven News.\n\nThe siblings went to Coachella music festival a week before they crossed into Mexico with their American friend, planning \"to surf for a few days,\" parents Martin and Debra Robinson said last week.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" they said in a statement before departing Perth, Western Australia.\n\nCallum, 33, was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and a Stevenson University alumnus. He was based in San Diego, California.\n\nIn an Instagram post, the Maryland college said, \"Callum will be remembered for his infectious spirit and larger-than-life personality.\"\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" the post said. \"Though he may be gone, Callum's legacy will live on in our hearts forever.\"\n\nCallum's friend Hayley Jacobs told CNN affiliate Nine News that he \"lit up a room.\"\n\nShe said she saw him on the morning he left for Mexico, but quickly felt something was wrong when she didn't hear from him.\n\n\"I don't know what's going on but I think he's mad at me, like something doesn't seem right,\" she said.\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nDrug cartels have terrorized the country with ever-increasing levels of violence and cruelty, fueled in part by huge demand for drugs from US consumers and armed with an arsenal of weaponry from north of the border.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThe latest suspected murders sparked outrage in the surf community of Ensenda, where about 500 people marched on Sunday to call for justice and better security, Australian public broadcaster ABC reported.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada told the ABC.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother resident, Ana Acosta, told the ABC: \"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers.\"\n\nIn a statement Sunday, Mexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences over the suspected killings.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nThis is a breaking news story and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. Australia Found at Bottom of Well in Mexico Died", "body": "Brothers Jake Robinson, 30, Callum Robinson, 33, and Jack Carter Rhoad, 30, were last seen on April 27 before being discovered dead\n\nNow, two brothers from Australia and their friend from the U.S. who all traveled to Mexico in April for a fun getaway are dead, and authorities have revealed why.\n\nAustralian brothers Jake Robinson, 30, of Victoria, Callum Robinson, 33, of San Diego, and American Jack Carter Rhoad, 30, also of San Diego, were last seen on April 27 while they were surfing and camping along the Mexican coast, south of Ensenada.\n\nThey were reported missing after they failed to show up at the accommodations they had booked in Rosarito, Debra Robinson, the brothers' mother, posted on Facebook, the Associated Press reports.\n\nAuthorities searching for the men found three bodies at the bottom of a well 50 feet deep in a desolate section of Santo Tomas, Baja California, FBI San Diego said in a statement Friday, NBC San Diego reports.\n\nAll three had suffered gunshot wounds.\n\nAt a press conference Sunday, Baja California's chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez Andrade Ram\u00edrez said they believe the three men were killed for their truck, because the killers wanted the tires, the Associated Press reports.\n\nShe said she believes the killers spotted the tents the three surfers had set up, saw the truck and wanted to steal the tires, the AP reports.\n\n\"When (the surfers) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted,\" she said.\n\nThey men were likely killed when they fought off the robbers, she said.\n\nTheir relatives identified the bodies, which were found about four miles from where they were killed, Ramirez said on Sunday.\n\nA fourth body was found in the well, she said.\n\nWant to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.\n\nThe thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nAuthorities worked for two hours to get the bodies out of the well, she said, the AP reports. Police are questioning three people they believe may be connected to the crime, she said.\n\n\"A working team (of investigators) is at the site where they were last seen, where tents and other evidence was found that could be linked to these three people we have under investigation,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said. \"There is a lot of important information that we can't make public.\"\n\nLater on Sunday, surfers honored the slain men by forming a circle floating on their boards in the ocean in a \"paddle-out\" ceremony, the AP reports.\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, the BBC reports.\n\nCallam moved to the U.S. to pursue his dream of becoming a professional lacrosse player, his parents, Deborah and Martin Robinson, said, the BBC reports.\n\nJake was taking Mexico - UrduPoint", "body": "The corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad, who were on a surf trip to Mexico's Pacific coast.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" a statement said.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers described the news as \"horrendous\" and said the \"whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them,\" he said.\n\nMexico's foreign minister Alicia Barcena expressed her condolences in a statement, saying that her office \"maintained a constant and direct dialogue with the Australian Ambassador to Mexico, Rachel Elizabeth Moseley, and her team, to support the efforts of the diplomatic mission.\"\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to Mexican prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and The fourth had been there as long as a month.\n\nPolice are currently investigating three Mexican nationals in connection with the case.\n\nTwo men and a woman have been detained on suspicion of direct or indirect involvement in the attack, the BBC reported.\n\nOne of the men has been charged with 'forced disappearance', or kidnapping.\n\nProtesters took to the streets of Ensenada, carrying surfboards with Spanish slogans on Sunday.\n\nOne said: 'They only wanted to surf - we demand safe beaches.'\n\nAnother said: 'Ensenada is a mass grave.'\n\nDozens of surfers gathered for a 'paddle-out' ceremony on the water as a vigil for the three murdered men.\n\nEnsenada is deemed relatively safe and has long been popular with tourists from California just to its north.\n\nBut Baja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, gripped by gang violence.\n\nThe risk of crime and kidnapping is so high, the US State Department advises Americans to reconsider travel there.\n\nHowever, prosecutor Andrade Ram\u00edrez refused to speculate on the involvement of organised crime, and whether the shots to the head were an execution.\n\nShe said: 'The investigation has only just begun.'\n\nThe FBI and Australian Federal Police are assisting Mexican authorities in the investigation.\n\nJake, who was about to start a new job as a doctor in Victoria, had been on 'the trip of a lifetime' to visit his brother Callum, who was living in the US.\n\nThey had visited Coachella music festival in the US before heading to Mexico to surf.\n\nTheir parents, Deborah and Martin Robinson, said: 'Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart.'\n\nCallum's girlfriend, Emily Horwath, said her heart was 'shattered into a million pieces', in an Instagram post with pictures of the couple.\n\nHis teammates at Stevenson University Lacrosse club, where he was chasing his dream of becoming a professional lacrosse player, called him larger than life.\n\nIn a statement, they said: 'With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' - warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand.'\n\nThere have been more than 30,000 murders a year in Mexico, for more than six consecutive years.\n\nLast year seven people were killed when a band of gunmen invaded a holiday resort in Mexican state of Guanajuato.\n\nThree men and three women as well as a seven-year-old child were gunned down at the La Palma resort in the small town of Cortazar.\n\nIn 2015, Australian surfers Adam Coleman and Dean Lucas were murdered in the Sinaloa region, next to Baja California, The Guardian reported.\n\nThey are believed to have been shot by gang members before their van and bodies were burnt.\n\nMORE : Woman arrested after five-month-old baby suffers {"uri": "8113035443", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:46:59", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:46:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:45:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/bodies-of-australian-us-surfers-found-in-mexico-had-bullet-wounds-to-the-head-8879139.html", "title": "Bodies Of Australian, US Surfers Found In Mexico Had Bullet Wounds To The Head - News18", "body": "The relatives of the deceased identified the bodies after they were retrieved from a pit near Mexico's Tijuana.\n\nThree bodies were identified by relatives Sunday as those of two Australians and an American shot dead during a suspected botched robbery during a surfing trip to Mexico, authorities said.\n\nThe corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of holidaying Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle -- which had been burned -- was found nearby.\n\nThe bodies \"all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile,\" Andrade said, adding that the friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed in a statement that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake, and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometers) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which locals said was solved far more quickly than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nThe three men were on a camping and surfing trip along a stretch of coast south of the city of Ensenada, posting idyllic photos on social media of waves and isolated beaches, before they went missing last weekend.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez described what likely would have been moments of terror that ended the trip for brothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nShe theorized the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tires. {"uri": "8113028638", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "02:36:39", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T02:36:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T02:35:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/world/mexico-bodies-of-murdered-australian-us-surfers-identified-by-relatives-13767457.html", "title": "Mexico: Bodies of murdered Australian, US surfers identified by relatives", "body": "People watch surfers taking part in a ceremony in honor of two Australians and an American surfers that went missing last week during a surfing trip at San Miguel Beach in Ensenada, Baja California State, Mexico. AFP\n\nRelatives on Sunday identified the bodies of two Australians and an American shot dead in a suspected botched robbery during a surfing trip to Mexico, authorities said.\n\nThe corpses were found with bullet wounds to their heads, according to officials in crime-hit Baja California state, suggesting an execution-style triple homicide.\n\nThe news confirmed the worst fears of the families and friends of holidaying Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend Jack Carter.\n\nThe trio were believed to have been murdered during an attempt to steal their pick-up truck, state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade said at a press conference.\n\nThe vehicle - which had been burned - was found nearby.\n\nThe state prosecutor's office later confirmed in a statement that the bodies had been formally identified as those of the missing surfers.\n\n\"The victims' relatives were able to identify them without the need for genetic tests,\" it said.\n\nThree suspects, two men and one woman, have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, according to prosecutors.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said.\n\nInvestigators said earlier that the bodies were recovered from a cliff-top shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition.\"\n\nAnother corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nAFP journalists saw authorities use a pulley system to extract the mud-covered bodies from the shaft on Friday near the town of Santo Thomas, about 30 miles (45 kilometers) southeast of Ensenada.\n\n'Tragic loss'\n\nThe Australian brothers' mother, Debra Robinson, had sounded the alarm on a Facebook page for Baja California tourists several days ago, after the young men dropped out of contact.\n\n\"Reaching out to anyone who has seen my two sons. They have not contacted us since Saturday 27th April,\" she wrote, attaching a poster from friends desperate for news of their whereabouts.\n\nA missing poster shared on social media said Callum Robinson was 33 and his brother Jake was 30. It named their friend as Jack Carter Rhoad, aged 30.\n\nThe friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems, Andrade said.\n\nCallum Robinson's Instagram page showed several images from the trio's Mexico trip: enjoying beers with their feet up in a bar, lazing in a jacuzzi, eating roadside tacos, looking out at the surf.\n\nSix-foot-four (1.93 meters) Callum had played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which left a message on its website saying the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the trio.\n\n\"We offer our hearts, support and prayers to the Robinson and Rhoad Families, as well as all who loved Callum, Jake and Jack,\" it said.\n\nJake Robinson was a doctor in Perth, according to Australian media.\n\nBaja California is known for its inviting beaches, and its resorts are popular with US tourists, partly because of their proximity to the border.\n\nIt is also one of Mexico's most violent states because of organized crime gangs, although cartel activity doesn't commonly affect foreign tourists.\n\nDozens of surfers protested in Ensenada on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths.\"\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered and their bodies burned while traveling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nCriminal violence in Mexico has claimed 450,000 lives and led to more than 100,000 disappearances since the end of 2006, when the government launched a controversial anti-drug strategy {"uri": "8113195400", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:40:06", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:40:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:37:17Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/3-bodies-found-mexico-identified-052443231.html", "title": "3 bodies found in Mexico identified as 2 Australians, American killed in carjacking on surfing trip", "body": "SAN DIEGO -- The remains of three people found near the Mexican fishing port of Ensenada are those of missing surfers from Australia and the U.S. who were killed in an apparent carjacking, authorities said Sunday.\n\nFamily members made the identifications in person at the behest of Baja California state prosecutors, the state attorney general's office said in a statement Sunday obtained by NBC San Diego. The bodies had been recovered from a remote well about 50 feet deep, authorities said.\n\nThe attorney general's office said the bodies, found in La Bocana, south of Ensenada, are those of Jake and Callum Robinson, of Australia, and Jack Carter Rhoad, of the U.S.\n\nAt least two of the three were believed to be living in San Diego, authorities said, according to NBC San Diego.\n\nThe Ensenada medical examiner's office said Friday the three victims were killed by gunshot wounds to the head.\n\nAt a news conference Sunday, prosecutors said that the motive was carjacking and that the assailants may have been particularly focused on the wheels of the pickup truck used by the missing surfers.\n\nThe three were at a makeshift encampment during a fishing and surfing trip south of Ensenada, where the Baja coast rapidly becomes remote and filled with surprises for surfers seeking relatively rare rides.\n\nProsecutors said they found the trio's encampment, including tents, spent gun shells, bloodstains and marks indicating bodies had been dragged.\n\nThree people were being questioned in connection with the case, authorities said. Two of the three, a man and a woman, were held on methamphetamine-related allegations, they said, and the third was the subject of a kidnapping warrant.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said previously there may be evidence, including a victim's cellphone in the possession of one of the three, that might connect the trio to the case.\n\nA fourth body was discovered with the three in the well and may be part of an unrelated case, authorities said.\n\nOn Sunday, Andrade Ram\u00edrez met with the three men's parents, her office said in its announcement identifying the bodies.\n\nShe reassured them, it said, that she was committed to ensuring those responsible face the full weight of the law.\n\nThe three men were considered missing on April 27 when they did not return to an Airbnb rental closer to the border, in Rosarito, Debra Robinson, the mother of Jake and Callum Robinson, said on Facebook.\n\nCartel and big-city street violence attributed to the drug trade in places like Tijuana has been seen as rare in the world of Baja tourism, which requires off-road-capable vehicles and the ability to start a campfire.\n\nThe peninsula's Pacific {"uri": "8113746727", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:06:03", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:06:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:05:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6392157077789307, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.nl/3-surfers-shot-in-the-head-while-visiting-mexico-were-found-dead-in-a-well-in-an-area-where-tourists-are-usually-safe/", "title": "3 surfers shot in the head while visiting Mexico were found dead in a well, in an area where tourists are usually safe", "body": "Three men were found dead in a well in Baja California, Mexico, after being shot on a surfing trip. Officials believe the tourists were attacked by three people who attempted to steal their truck. The incident has sparked protests in Ensenada, demanding safety for tourists and locals alike.\n\nThree men in their early 30s have been found dead in a well after being shot in the head while on a surfing trip in Baja California, Mexico.\n\nTwo Australian brothers, Callum and Jake Robinson, and their American friend, Jack Carter Rhoad, were near the popular coastal town of Ensenada when they went missing last week.\n\nTheir bodies were found in the 15-foot-deep well on Saturday after a dayslong search, and have since been identified by family members, Reuters reported.\n\nJake, 30, had flown to the US to visit Callum, 33, who was pursuing his dream of being a professional lacrosse player. The week after his trip, Jake was due to start a new job as a doctor in Victoria, Australia. Carter Rhoad, 30, was working as an apparel designer in San Diego, the New York Post reported.\n\nThey were last seen on 27 April and, when they didn't show up to an Airbnb booking a couple of days later, were reported missing and an investigation was launched by local authorities and the FBI.\n\nIt's thought that the tourists were attacked after they defended themselves from three people who were trying to steal their truck.\n\nBaja California state prosecutor Maria Andrade suggested that the attackers wanted the truck for its tires and shot the three men in their heads when they resisted, Reuters reported.\n\nA burnt-out vehicle suspected to be the surfers' truck was also found in the area, alongside abandoned tents, and a phone linked to them.\n\nThree Mexican nationals, two men and a woman, have been arrested as suspects.\n\nA fourth body was also found in the well, but it's believed to be older and from an earlier incident, the Guardian reported.\n\nTurf wars between drug gangs are common in Baja California, which is one of Mexico's most dangerous and violent states. However, Ensenada is generally considered to be safe -- about 75 miles south of California, it is a popular spot for US tourists.\n\nThe surfers' loved ones have paid tribute\n\nFriends and family of the Robinsons and Carter Rhoad have been sharing tributes to the young men.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" the brothers' parents said in a statement, the BBC reported.\n\nCallum's teammates from Stevenson University Lacrosse Club said in a statement on social media: \"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand.\"\n\nHis girlfriend, Emily Horwath, said in an Instagram story that her heart was \"shattered into a million pieces.\"\n\nView this post on Instagram\n\nA post shared by Emily Horwath (@emily_livia)\n\n\"I don't have the words right now... I will love you forever,\" she wrote.\n\nProtesters and mourners took to the streets of Ensenada on Sunday to share their sadness and anger.\n\nThey marched with messages on surfboards, such as \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nSurfers also held a \"paddle out\" ocean vigil in memory of the Robinsons and Carter Rhoad.\n\nRead the original article on Business Insider", {"uri": "8113073914", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:33:12", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:33:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:32:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/mexico/3-bodies-found-mexico-identified-missing-surfers-rcna150790", "title": "3 bodies found in Mexico identified as missing surfers", "body": "SAN DIEGO -- The remains of three people found near the Mexican fishing port of Ensenada are those of missing surfers from Australia and the U.S. who were killed in an apparent carjacking, authorities said Sunday.\n\nFamily members made the identification in-person at the behest of Baja California state prosecutors, the state attorney general's office said in a statement Sunday obtained by NBC San Diego. The bodies had been recovered from a remote well about 50 feet deep, authorities said.\n\n\"The Attorney General's Office of the State of Baja California confirms that the bodies found in the well in the area known as La Bocana, south of Ensenada, correspond to those of Jake and Callum Robinson, of Australian origin, as well as the American, Jack Carter,\" it said.\n\nAt least two of the three were believed to be living in San Diego, authorities said, according to NBC San Diego.\n\nThe Ensenada medical examiner's office said Friday the three victims were killed by gunshot wounds to the head.\n\nAt a Sunday news conference, prosecutors said the motive was carjacking, and the assailants may have been particularly focused on the wheels of the pickup used by the missing surfers.\n\nThe bodies were discovered Friday in a well in an area called La Bocana, authorities said.\n\nThe three were at a makeshift encampment during a fishing trip south of Ensenada, where the Baja coast rapidly becomes remote and filled with surprises for surfers seeking relatively rare rides.\n\nProsecutors said they found the trio's encampment, including tents, spent gun shells, blood stains, and marks indicating bodies were dragged.\n\nThree people were being questioned in connection with the case, authorities said. Two of the three, a man and woman, were held on suspicion of methamphetamine-related allegations, they said, and the fourth was the subject of a kidnapping warrant.\n\nChief state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said previously there may be evidence, including a victim's cell phone in the possession of one of the three, that may connect the trio to the case.\n\nA fourth body was discovered with the three in the well and may be part of an unrelated case, authorities said.\n\nOn Sunday, Andrade Ram\u00edrez met with the parents of the three men, her office said in its announcement that the bodies had been positively identified.\n\nShe reassured them, it said, that she was committed to ensuring those responsible face the full weight of the law, according to the statement.\n\nThe three men were considered missing on April 27 when they did not return to an Airbnb closer to the border, in Rosarito, the mother of Jake and Callum Robinson, Debra Robinson, said on Facebook.\n\nCartel and big-city street violence attributed to the drug trade in places like Tijuana has been seen as rare in the world of Baja tourism that requires off-road-capable vehicles and the ability to start a camp fire.\n\nThe peninsula's Pacific coast has been a staple destination for United States surfers for 60 years. but the U.S. State Department has more recently urged Americans to {"uri": "8113075347", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:34:40", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:34:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:33:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6352941393852234, "url": "https://gazette.com/news/us-world/parents-identify-bodies-of-u-s-australian-tourists-missing-in-mexico/article_a32e08c1-6c86-531f-9582-361168b0dce0.html", "title": "Parents identify bodies of U.S., Australian tourists missing in Mexico", "body": "Members of the United States and Australian embassies and the parents of missing U.S. and Australian tourists leave the Forensic Medical Service (Servicio Medico Forense) after the parents identified that the three bodies found earlier are their children's, in Ensenada, Mexico, May 5, 2024. REUTERS/Jorge Duenes\n\nBy Raul Cortes and Lizbeth Diaz\n\nMEXICO CITY (Reuters) -Mexican authorities on Sunday confirmed the American and two Australian tourists who went missing in northern Mexico last week are dead after their bodies were identified by parents.\n\nThe bodies of Australian brothers Callum, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, as well as American Carter Rhoad, 30, were found at the bottom of a well in Baja California state earlier this week after a days-long search.\n\nThe three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nSHOT BY CAR THIEVES\n\nThree people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer. The U.S. State Department advises Americans to reconsider travel to the state due to crime and kidnapping.\n\n(Reporting by Raul Cortes and Lizbeth Diaz, additional reporting by Lewis Jackson in Sydney; Writing by Drazen Jorgic, editing by Deepa Babington and Michael Perry)\n\nSign Up for Springs AM Update Your morning rundown of the latest news from Colorado Springs and around the country\n\nSign Up View all of our newsletters. {"uri": "8114291173", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:43:48", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:43:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T18:37:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13388373/How-beach-trip-Mexicos-Baja-California-turned-deadly-surfers-Australia-US.html", "title": "How a beach trip in Mexico's Baja California turned deadly for...", "body": "MEXICO CITY (AP) - Two Australians and an American were doing what they loved on the stunning, largely isolated stretch of Baja California's Pacific coast. Their last images on social media showed them sitting and gazing at the waves, contemplating the breaks.\n\nWhat happened to end their lives may have been as random as a passing pickup truck full of people with ill intent. The surfers were shot in the head, their bodies dumped in a covered well miles away. How it unfolded was the stuff of nightmares.\n\nBrothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad had apparently stopped to surf the breaks at Punta San Jos\u00e9, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) south of Ensenada. They were attacked there on April 28 or 29.\n\nAs soon as police arrived at their last known camp site, it was clear that something had gone violently wrong.\n\nThere were bloodstains and marks \"as if heavy objects had been dragged,\" leading to suspicions of an attack, the Baja California state prosecutor's office said in an attempt to reconstruct the scene.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez told a press conference on Sunday that the killers apparently drove by, saw the foreigners\u00b4 pickup truck and wanted to steal its tires and other parts.\n\nThe photos of the foreign surfers who disappeared are placed on the beach in Ensenada, Mexico, Sunday, May 5, 2024. Mexican authorities said Friday that three bodies were recovered in an area of Baja California near where two Australians and an American went missing last weekend during an apparent camping and surfing trip. (AP Photo/Karen Castaneda)\n\nSuch was the banality of evil, she said, that \"they were not attacked because they were tourists. ... The evidence suggests they (the killers) did not know where they were from.\"\n\nThe foreigners surely resisted, she said. \"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun, and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then the other two came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez said the reconstruction of events was based on the forensic examiner's reports, noting all three had bullet wounds to the head.\n\nThere was a hurried attempt to destroy evidence. The foreigners\u00b4 tents were apparently burned. The pickup truck was driven miles away and burned. The assailants' truck was later found with a gun inside.\n\nThen, at \"a site that is extremely hard to get to,\" the bodies were dumped into a well about 4 miles (6 kilometers) away. Investigators were surprised when, underneath the bodies of the three foreigners, a fourth body was found that had been there much longer.\n\n\"They had to have previous knowledge of it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said of the attackers, acknowledging the possibility they were behind the previous killing.\n\nThe well had been covered with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said. It took two hours to winch the bodies out.\n\nProsecutors have said they were questioning three people in the killings. Two were caught with methamphetamines. One of them, a woman, had one of the victims' cellphones when she was caught. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third man was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means quesadillas, or cheese tortillas.\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record that included drug dealing, vehicle theft and domestic violence, adding, \"We are certain that more people were involved.\"\n\nShe emphasized that she could not discuss anything related to the suspects, or their possible statements, because that was not allowed under Mexican law and might prejudice the case against them.\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez noted that the victims' families said the brothers and Rhoad had come many times to the seaside spot and never had any problem. This time, however, \"there was no way to ask for help when the attackers showed up.\"", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "2024-04-28", "textStart": 728, "textEnd": 736}], "sentiment": -0.2784313725490196, "wgt": 161, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "8114172020", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:57:46", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:57:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:57:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://globalnews.ca/news/10476525/missing-australian-american-surfers-dead-mexico/", "title": "Missing Australian, American surfers found dead in well with gunshot wounds - National | Globalnews.ca", "body": "Three surfers who went missing in Mexico over a week ago have been confirmed dead after their bodies were identified by relatives, Mexican officials announced Sunday.\n\nIt's believed the men were victims of a violent carjacking. One person has been charged and two others are currently in police custody in connection with the men's deaths.\n\nAustralian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad were found dead at the bottom of a 15-metre well about six kilometres away from their camping site. They had each been shot in the head, the State Attorney General's Office of Baja California said.\n\nThe three men had been camping and surfing together along the Baja coast in the municipality of Ensenada, about an hour and a half south of the U.S.-Mexico border, when they failed to show up at the Airbnb they had booked for the April 27-28 weekend.\n\nOn Thursday, Mexican officials announced they had found the men's campsite and were investigating \"other evidence\" at the location. Three people were brought in for questioning.\n\nDuring a Sunday news conference, Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, the state's chief prosecutor, revealed that the surfers' tents were found burned to the ground and gun casings, blood stains and drag marks were present at the site, which led investigators to believe the victims had been attacked and their bodies moved.\n\nAfter an extensive search, investigators found a boarded-up well about six kilometres away from the campsite in an \"extremely\" remote area. Inside were four bodies: the three tourists who had gone missing, as well as a fourth, older body.\n\nThe three men's bodies had likely been in the well for five to seven days by the time they were found, according to NBC San Diego, citing a local medical examiner. The fourth body had been there much longer and may be from an unrelated homicide case, or could have been dumped there by the same people who killed the tourists.\n\nRam\u00edrez hypothesized that the three men were killed by armed robbers who wanted to steal the tires and other parts from their truck. She believes the attackers drove by the tourists' campsite, noticed their pickup truck and intended to steal parts to put on their own, older-model truck.\n\nThe men are believed to have fought back against the robbers, who then took out a firearm and shot them to death. In order to cover up the crime, the attackers disposed of the bodies in the nearby well and burned evidence.\n\nLocal media reported that parts stolen from the surfers' truck were found in another truck belonging to one of the suspects brought in by police.\n\nA man identified only as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" who also goes by the alias \"El Kekas,\" a slang word for quesadillas, was charged with forced disappearance by state prosecutors before the men's bodies were identified. It's unclear if he will face upgraded charges now that the surfers have been confirmed dead. Mexican authorities only release the first names of people charged with crimes.\n\nJes\u00fas Gerardo has a prior criminal record, prosecutors said.\n\nTwo other people, a man and a woman, remain in police custody as investigators probe their involvement in the deaths. Both were arrested with methamphetamines in their possession.\n\nAll three suspects are Mexican nationals.\n\nMembers of the local surfing community in Ensenada gathered at the beach to pay respects to the three men who died.\n\n\"Ensenada is a mass grave,\" read one protester's poster.\n\n\"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches,\" another sign read.\n\nDozens of surfers paddled out into the ocean with flowers on their boards and formed a circle, before throwing the flowers into the waves as part of Sunday's vigil.\n\nBaja California is considered one of the most dangerous states in Mexico, despite the strong tourism industry there.\n\nThe federal government advises all Canadian travellers to exercise a \"high degree of caution in Mexico due to high levels of criminal activity and kidnapping.\" The advisory warns that border and rural areas often see the highest amount of criminal activity.\n\nIt's recommended that travellers stay in hotels and resorts with good security, One of the suspects was identified as Jes\u00fas Gerardo \"N,\" alias \"El Kekas.\"\n\nThe three friends were on a surfing and camping trip near the town of Ensenada, about 60 miles south of the border city of Tijuana, when they went missing on April 29, and are believed to have been murdered, according to authorities.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez met with parents of the victims on Sunday and \"reaffirmed the institution's total commitment to continue the investigation into these unfortunate events until those responsible are fully prosecuted by the law,\" she said.\n\nThe surfers may have been attacked in an attempted vehicle robbery, officials said, citing preliminary investigations. Baja California has been plagued by cartel violence in recent years, though it rarely occurs in tourist areas like Ensenada.\n\nA burned-out white pickup truck was found at a ranch in Santo Tomas, about 40 miles from where the bodies were found, a local police source told CNN. The vehicle was confirmed to be the same one Callum Robinson posted an image of on Instagram a week before the trio went missing.\n\nMexico's Foreign Ministry expressed its condolences in a statement Sunday.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" it said.\n\nWhile parts of Mexico are established tourist destinations, violent crime including kidnapping and human trafficking plague parts of the country, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate is among the highest in the world, and more than 100,000 people remain missing in the country.\n\nIn 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were found in a burned-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities said they were killed by low-level drug dealers who had been robbing motorists.\n\nThis is a breaking news story and will be updated.\n\nThe-CNN-Wire\n\n\u2122 & \u00a9 2024 Cable News Network, Inc., a Warner Bros. {"uri": "8113093634", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "03:57:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T03:57:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T03:53:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6235294342041016, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/parents-identify-bodies-of-u-s-australian-tourists-missing-in-mexico/2071480/", "title": "Parents identify bodies of U.S., Australian tourists missing in Mexico", "body": "The three foreigners went missing while on a vacation surfing near the popular tourist town of Ensenada, about 90 minutes south of the U.S.-Mexico border on the Pacific coast.\n\nBaja California state Attorney General's Office said in a statement the confirmation was issued once the parents of the victims \"were able to identify them, without the need of genetic tests\".\n\nState Attorney General Elena Andrade told the parents and diplomatic officials that there was \"total institutional commitment to continue with the investigation of these unfortunate events until those responsible receive the full weight of the law\", the statement added.\n\nOn Saturday, Andrade said that the bodies were found in an advanced state of decomposition at the bottom of a well more than 15 meters (50 ft) deep.\n\nA source from the attorney general's office told Reuters that all three bodies had a shot in the head.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers offered his condolences to the families of Callum and Jake and said the whole country mourned with them.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said at a news conference.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nThree people have so far been arrested, officials say. A burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the three surfers was also found in the area.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the arrested individuals attempted to carjack the foreigners and when the surfers resisted they were shot and their bodies dumped in a well.\n\nThe three surfers were last seen on April 27 and reported missing a couple of days later, when authorities launched a multi-day search with the help from the U.S. Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI).\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, although the Ensenada area is considered safer. The U.S. State Department advises Americans to reconsider travel to the state due to crime and kidnapping.\n\n(Reporting by Raul Cortes and Lizbeth Diaz, additional reporting by Lewis Jackson in {"uri": "2024-05-346028477", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:08:33", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:08:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T06:26:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/three-bodies-found-mexico-had-234122315.html", "title": "Surfers found dead in Mexico well were shot in head", "body": "Three tourists found dead in Mexico were shot in the head and their bodies dumped in a well, authorities have confirmed.\n\nAustralian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson, 30 and 33, and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad, 30, disappeared on 27 April while on a surfing trip in Ensenada.\n\nRelatives of the three men identified their bodies on Sunday after travelling to Mexico to assist authorities, a state prosecutor said.\n\nOfficials believe the men were attacked trying to stop the theft of their pickup truck.\n\nThe attackers wanted the vehicle for its tyres and shot the tourists when they resisted, Baja California state prosecutor Maria Andrade suggested.\n\nTheir bodies were found in a 4m (15ft) deep well about 6km (4 miles) from the site of the attack in the town of Santo Tom\u00e1s on Friday.\n\nAbandoned tents, a burnt white pickup truck and a phone linked to the missing surfers were found nearby.\n\nA fourth body was found in the well but had been there longer and was unconnected to the case, officials said.\n\nTwo men and a woman have been detained on suspicion of direct or indirect involvement in the attack. One man has been charged with \"forced disappearance\".\n\nEarlier, the FBI said it was looking into the case and was in touch with international partners.\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, as local drug gangs fight turf wars.\n\nBut the Ensenada area, about 120km (75 miles) south of the US-Mexico border and known for its surfing conditions, is considered safer and has long attracted tourists from California.\n\nThe brothers' parents - Deborah and Martin Robinson - said Callum had been living in the US, chasing his dream of becoming a professional lacrosse player.\n\nJake was on \"the trip of lifetime\" to visit him before starting a new job in Victoria as a doctor, they said on Friday.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart.\"\n\nFriends of the brothers have also flooded social media with tributes.\n\nCallum's teammates at Stevenson University Lacrosse club said the athlete was a larger-than-life personality.\n\n\"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' - warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand,\" a statement from the club said.\n\nHis girlfriend, Emily Horwath, said her heart was \"shattered into a million pieces\".\n\n\"I don't have the words right now... I will love you forever,\" she wrote in a post on Instagram, alongside pictures of the couple.\n\nCarter Rhoad's social media accounts showed happy snaps of him proposing to his partner less than a year ago.\n\nA fundraiser set up by friends of his family said he and the Robinson brothers had \"brought immeasurable joy, love, and kindness\" to the world.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the country was thinking of the Robinson family.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today,\" he said at a news conference on Monday.\n\nThe killings have sparked fear and anger in the Ensenada region.\n\nScores of protesters marched through the city on Sunday, carrying surfboards plastered with slogans written in Spanish.\n\n\"They only wanted to surf - we demand safe beaches,\" one said. \"Australia we are with you,\" another said.\n\nA group of surfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony, an ocean {"uri": "8113486018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "09:16:08", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T09:16:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T09:15:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6196078658103943, "url": "https://www.thescottishsun.co.uk/news/12624488/callum-jake-robinson-carter-rhoad-mexico-missing-identified/", "title": "Body of US tourist murdered in cartel territory identified as cops vow justice", "body": "MISSING tourists Callum and Jake Robinson as well as their friend Carter Rhoad have been identified as the bodies that were pulled from a well on Friday.\n\nThe victims' family members confirmed the awful truth on Sunday in Mexico after a week-long search.\n\nThere will be no need to identify the bodies with genetic testing, the state attorney general's office said in a statement.\n\nBrothers Callum and Jake were accompanied by Rhoad, an American, when they went missing in Baja California while they were on a surfing trip.\n\nThey were reported missing by Debra Robinson when they never showed up to their Airbnb over the weekend and she had lost contact with her sons.\n\nTheir bodies were found in a 50-foot well next to a cliff at Punta San Jos\u00e9 in Santo Tom\u00e1s, in the municipality of Ensenada, near a remote surfing spot known as Lighthouse, reports the San Diego Union-Tribune.\n\nIt was about four miles from where the trio was camping and believed to have been killed.\n\nInvestigators believe the men were attacked by people who wanted to steal their truck for tires.\n\n\"The attackers drove by [the travelers' campsite] in their vehicle,\" Baja California prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said, according to The Guardian.\n\n\"They approached, with the intention of stealing their vehicle and taking the tires and other parts to put them on the older-model pickup they were driving.\n\n\"Upon approaching and surprising [the missing men], there was surely resistance and these people, the attackers, took out a firearm they had and took their lives.\n\n\"When what was meant to be a robbery had got out of control, they tried to dispose of the bodies by throwing them into a well.\n\n\"They were not attacked because they were tourists, the intent was to steal their vehicle.\"\n\nThe men were shot in the head and the suspects allegedly dragged their bodies into a pick-up truck to transport them to the well, according to El Financiero.\n\nOn Thursday, Ramirez said police found the tourists' white pickup truck on fire while searching for the men.\n\nThey also found tents that were said to have belonged to the men and boards over the well where their bodies were later found.\n\nThe location of their campsite was hard to access with no cell service or internet, thus pointing towards a robbery, according to Ramirez.\n\nThat also was a factor in ruling out that the area was controlled by the Mexican cartel, according to El Financiero.\n\nIn about six to seven days, their bodies already began to show signs of decomposition, according to the general director of forensic sciences of the Attorney General's Office of the State of Baja California.\n\nRam\u00edrez said she was committed to investigating \"these unfortunate events until those responsible feel the full weight of the law,\" according to The Guardian.\n\n\"The investigation has only just begun.\"\n\nTwo brothers and a 23-year-old woman are currently being questioned by police, according to ABC News Australia.\n\nOne of the individuals has been charged with kidnapping, while the other two are being held for crystal meth, according to The Guardian.\n\nA picture of a woman was released as she was found with one of the missing men's phones and a bag of drugs, according to Ramirez.\n\nThe prosecutor is certain that more people took part in the attack.\n\n\"In fact, we are sure that more people took part in the attack,\" she said.\n\nOne of the suspects, identified him only by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, or \"el Kekas\", a slang word that means quesadillas, is believed to have directly participated in the murders, according to The Guardian.\n\nMourners in Ensenada, the nearest city, came together to share their sadness about the deaths.\n\nSurfers wrote messages on signs and surfboards, in Spanish, reading, \"Ensenada is a mass grave\" and \"Australia, we are with you.\"\n\nOn Sunday evening, surfers gathered in San Miguel for a paddle out, a vigil performed on the water.\n\n\"I'm just shaken to my core,\" said Gino Passalacqua, the vice-president of the Baja Surf Club who said he had lived in Baja since 2009, according to The Guardian.\n\nPeople collected at the beach as surfers paddled out to sea with flowers on their boards to honor the lost men.\n\nSurfboard maker Eduardo Echegaray said, \"We're all brothers. In the water, it doesn't matter what country we're from, we're all brothers,\" according to The Guardian.\n\nThe Baja California Surfing Association made a statement on the horrific events.\n\n\"This atrocious act has not only deeply impacted those of us who practice this sport, but has also shaken the foundations of our coastal community, which has always been a haven of peace and camaraderie among surf lovers,\" the association shared in a statement.\n\n\"We urge the competent authorities to carry out a thorough and transparent investigation to bring those responsible for this act of One man has been charged with \"forced disappearance\".\n\nEarlier, the FBI said it was looking into the case and was in touch with international partners.\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, as local drug gangs fight turf wars.\n\nBut the Ensenada area, about 120km (75 miles) south of the US-Mexico border and known for its surfing conditions, is considered safer and has long attracted tourists from California.\n\nThe killings have sparked fear and anger in the popular holiday spot.\n\nScores of protesters marched through the city on Sunday, carrying surfboards plastered with slogans written in Spanish.\n\n\"They only wanted to surf - we demand safe beaches,\" one said. \"Australia we are with you,\" another said.\n\nA group of surfers later performed a \"paddle-out\" ceremony, an ocean vigil to honor the trio.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers said the country was thinking of the Robinson family.\n\n\"It has been an absolutely horrendous, {"uri": "8114454670", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "21:13:29", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T21:13:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T21:12:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://lavocedinewyork.com/en/news/2024/05/06/three-tourists-killed-in-mexico-for-their-truck-tires/", "title": "Three Tourists Killed in Mexico for their Truck Tires", "body": "The bodies of three men found in Baja California have been identified as tourists that went missing in Mexico during a surfing and camping trip.\n\nAccording to Mexican officials, Jack Carter Rhoad, 30, from San Diego, California, and brothers Jake, 30, and Callum Robinson, 33, from Australia, were in a suspected vehicle robbery for their tires just over a week ago.\n\nThe group of tourists were found at the bottom of a 50-foot-deep water hole near the town of Santo Tom\u00e1s, Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, Baja California's attorney general, told reporters Friday. She also said a fourth body was discovered in the water hole, though the person is likely not connected to the others' deaths.\n\nRam\u00edrez said the three tourists were likely killed in a vehicle robbery gone amiss, suggesting they were shot in the head after they resisted perpetrators who wanted tires from their white pickup truck.\n\nRelatives of Rhoad and the Robinson brothers identified their bodies without needing a genetics test, Baja prosecutors said in a statement to the Associated Press.\n\nLast week, Jake and Callum's mother, Debra Robinson, wrote on Facebook that her sons had not contacted the family since April 27, indicating the brothers and an \"American citizen\" were scheduled to arrive at an Airbnb in Rosarito, Mexico, after a camping trip, but did not arrive.\n\nThree Mexican citizens have been arrested on the suspicion of kidnapping, as reported by Ram\u00edrez, who said one suspect was charged with forced disappearance, while the other two were charged with possession of methamphetamines.\n\nThe third suspect, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means \"quesadillas,\" was believed to have directly participated in the killings, said Ram\u00edrez.\n\nAccording to the attorney general, investigators hadn't ruled out whether local cartels were involved in the tourists' deaths, and the FBI is involved in an ongoing investigation.\n\nLast year, the State Department issued a travel advisory to Mexico, urging Americans to \"reconsider travel\" to Baja California because of crime and kidnapping. {"uri": "2024-05-346730885", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "16:26:17", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T16:26:17Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T16:13:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://inews.co.uk/news/world/warning-uk-tourists-mexico-surfers-shot-dead-3043016", "title": "UK tourists warned to be cautious in Mexico after surfers shot dead", "body": "Two Australians and an American were shot in the head by thieves who wanted their truck's tyres, prosecutors said, and their bodies dumped in a well\n\nBritish tourists heading to Mexico were warned on Monday to be cautious after the brutal \"execution-style\" killing of three surfers who travelled to a popular region of the country's Pacific coast.\n\nTwo Australians and an American were shot in the head by thieves who wanted their truck's tyres, prosecutors said.\n\nRelatives identified the bodies of Australian brothers Callum Robinson, 33, and Jake Robinson, 30, and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad, 30. Their remains were found near Ensenada in Baja California, near the US border.\n\nThe region is notorious for drug cartel killings but this violence rarely involves tourists. However, the latest murders raise fears over how safe Mexico is for holidaymakers.\n\nDanny Callaghan, CEO of the Latin American Travel Association (Lata), told : \"We were very saddened to hear of this incident and our thoughts are with the victims' families and loved ones.\n\n\"Whilst thousands of British travellers enjoy trouble-free trips to Mexico every year, we always advise checking the official Foreign Office advice and discussing your travel plans including specific areas and regions, with a reputable Lata tour operator prior to booking.\"\n\nDozens of surfers protested near where the victims' bodies were found on Sunday with messages written on their boards including \"beaches, security, freedom, peace\" and \"no more deaths\".\n\nPaulina Rodriguez, a Mexican surfer who took part in demonstrations calling for an end to the killings, paid homage to the trio.\n\n\"Normally it is only women who are scared to go surfing alone but this case shows that we are all vulnerable, that this kind of thing can happen to any of us,\" she told from Baja California.\n\nThe case echoes that of two Australian surfers who were murdered, and their bodies burned while travelling in the northwestern Mexican state of Sinaloa in November 2015.\n\nIn June, British woman Sophie Wiggins, 32, was seriously injured in Mexico after robbers broke into her jungle ranch and shot her and killed her Polish partner in the resort of Playa del Carmen.\n\nThe latest shootings come amid increasing concern that Mexico is in the grip of escalating drug gang violence.\n\nThe Foreign Commonwealth and Development Office has a list of advice for British tourists travelling to Mexico. \"Crime in Mexico can pose a risk for foreigners, particularly in major cities and tourist resorts where street crime is a serious issue,\" it says.\n\nFor decades, Mexico has been plagued by violence linked to drug cartels. Since 2006, 450,000 people have been killed and an estimated 100,000 disappeared, according to government statistics.\n\nNorthern Baja California, where the three surfers were killed, has one of the highest murder rates in Mexico, with between 50-100 killings per 100,000 people, according to a 2023 Mexican Citizen Council for Public Security and Justice report.\n\nMarina del Pinar, the state governor of Baja California, said in a statement to that despite the killings, the region was safe for tourists.\n\n\"Baja California is and will continue to be a secure place for people to visit from our country and from all over the world,\" she said.\n\nTwo men and a woman have been detained on suspicion of involvement in the case, said Mexican prosecutors. They were named by Mexican media as Jesus Gerardo aka \"El Kekas\", his girlfriend Ari Gisel, and his brother.\n\nOne of those arrested has a history of violence, drug dealing and robbery, officials said. The woman is facing drug charges.\n\nInvestigators said the bodies were recovered from a clifftop shaft in an \"advanced state of decomposition\". Another corpse found at the site had been there longer and was unconnected to the others, officials said.\n\nThe friends had previously visited Mexico several times without any problems, said chief state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez.\n\nJake was a doctor, while Callum played in the US Premier Lacrosse League, which said the lacrosse world was \"heartbroken by the tragic loss\" of the {"uri": "8113211574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "05:53:04", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T05:53:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:52:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5921568870544434, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/international/2928640-missing-american-and-australian-tourists-found-dead-in-mexico", "title": "Missing American and Australian tourists found dead in Mexico | International", "body": "The trio of friends vanished on April 29 while on a surfing and camping expedition near the town of Ensenada, approximately 60 miles south of Tijuana. Authorities believe they were victims of murder.\n\nThe discovery of three bodies, bearing gunshot wounds to the head and dumped in a well, has been confirmed as those of missing tourists, including a US citizen, Mexican authorities revealed Sunday, CNN reported. Relatives of American Jack Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson were able to positively identify the bodies without resorting to genetic tests, as stated by the Baja California Attorney General's office in a Sunday statement.\n\nFollowing the grim discovery, three Mexican citizens, previously questioned in connection with the tourists' disappearance, have been apprehended on suspicion of kidnapping, as announced by the attorney general's office. Among the suspects, one was identified as Jesus Gerardo \"N,\" also known as \"El Kekas,\" according to CNN. The trio of friends vanished on April 29 while on a surfing and camping expedition near the town of Ensenada, approximately 60 miles south of Tijuana. Authorities believe they were victims of murder.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez convened with the victims' parents on Sunday, reaffirming the institution's unwavering commitment to pursue the investigation until those accountable face full prosecution under the law. Authorities suggested that the surfers may have been targeted in an attempted vehicle robbery, citing preliminary probes. While Baja California has seen its share of cartel violence in recent years, such incidents are rare in tourist hubs like Ensenada.\n\nA charred white pickup truck, matching the one Callum Robinson had shared on Instagram a week before their disappearance, was discovered at a ranch in Santo Tomas, approximately 40 miles from the well where the bodies were found, revealed a local police source to CNN. Expressing condolences, Mexico's Foreign Ministry released a statement on Sunday, standing in solidarity with the victims' families and lamenting the tragic turn of events.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" the statement read. While certain regions of Mexico remain popular tourist destinations, the nation grapples with pervasive violent crimes, including kidnapping and human trafficking, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate ranks among the highest globally, with over 100,000 people still missing.\n\nIn a similar incident in 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were discovered in a burnt-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities attributed their deaths to low-level drug dealers engaged in robbery of motorists, CNN reported.
