Among the suspects, one was identified as Jesus Gerardo \"N,\" also known as \"El Kekas,\" according to CNN.\n\nThe trio of friends vanished on April 29 while on a surfing and camping expedition near the town of Ensenada, approximately 60 miles south of Tijuana. Authorities believe they were victims of murder.\n\nBaja California Attorney General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez convened with the victims' parents on Sunday, reaffirming the institution's unwavering commitment to pursue the investigation until those accountable face full prosecution under the law.\n\nAuthorities suggested that the surfers may have been targeted in an attempted vehicle robbery, citing preliminary probes. While Baja California has seen its share of cartel violence in recent years, such incidents are rare in tourist hubs like Ensenada.\n\nA charred white pickup truck, matching the one Callum Robinson had shared on Instagram a week before their disappearance, was discovered at a ranch in Santo Tomas, approximately 40 miles from the well where the bodies were found, revealed a local police source to CNN.\n\nExpressing condolences, Mexico's Foreign Ministry released a statement on Sunday, standing in solidarity with the victims' families and lamenting the tragic turn of events.\n\n\"The Foreign Ministry stands in solidarity with the families of the victims in this tragic event and deeply regrets the outcome of the events,\" the statement read.\n\nWhile certain regions of Mexico remain popular tourist destinations, the nation grapples with pervasive violent crimes, including kidnapping and human trafficking, particularly in border areas. Mexico's homicide rate ranks among the highest globally, with over 100,000 people still missing.\n\nIn a similar incident in 2015, the bodies of Australian surfers Dean Lucas and Adam Coleman were discovered in a burnt-out van in Sinaloa state. Authorities attributed their deaths to low-level drug dealers engaged in robbery of motorists, CNN reported. {"uri": "8113795826", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:38:52", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:38:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:37:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/galleries/article-13387251/Shock-theory-Aussie-brothers-killed-Mexico-surfing-trip.html", "title": "Shock theory about the Aussie brothers killed on Mexico surfing trip", "body": "A shocking new theory about the execution-style deaths of two Australian brothers and their American friend has raised fears over the possible involvement of drug cartels. Callum and Jake Robinson (pictured) and their American mate Jack Carter Rhoad were last seen on April 27 in the Mexican province of Baja California. Mexican authorities said bandits attacked the three to steal the tyres off their truck before killing them all and dumping their bodies in a disused well. But the style of the slayings - a single gunshot to the head - has sparked fears locally about the possible involvement of drug cartels, which are rife in the region.\n\nThe shock new details emerged as Callum and Jake's grieving parents performed the grim task of identifying their bodies on Sunday local time. The Baja California Forensic Medical Service released the autopsy results as heartbreaking footage emerged of the Aussies' parents leaving Ensenada Forensics Lab after identifying Callum's and Jake's bodies. Three Mexicans have already been arrested over the deaths but authorities are not ruling out further accomplices with possible links to organised crime. 'We cannot rule out the possibility that there are additional individuals who were involved in this incident,' local Attorney-General Mar\u00eda Andrade Ram\u00edrez said. She added that the victims 'all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile'.\n\nHundreds of people marched through the nearby town of Ensenada on Sunday afternoon, demanding greater security measures amid a welter of cartel-fuelled violence. Some held surfboards emblazoned with messages written in Spanish, including 'Australia, we are with you' and 'They only wanted to surf, and they executed them', according to the ABC . Baja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, with the US State Department advising Americans to reconsider travel there due to crime and kidnapping. Tijuana, 100km north of where the three surfers were found and close to the US border, is plagued by violence and has the most homicides of any city in Mexico.\n\nWith a population of more than two million, it regularly has around 2,000 murders a year. By comparison, Houston, Texas, which has a similar population, saw 435 killings in 2022, according to Associated Press. In December last year, furious drug lords hunted down corrupt officers who allegedly stole a drug shipment. The revenge hits led to the deaths of at least five officers. It is believed the region is riven by turf battles between the Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation cartels, in addition to other groups. In June last year, the city's mayor, Montserrat Caballero, announced she had decided to live at an army base for her own safety after receiving threats.\n\nEarlier, Daily Mail Australia revealed that Callum's devastated girlfriend Emily Horwath (pictured) shared a heartfelt tribute on social media. 'You are one of one,' she captioned a photo of the couple sharing a kiss. 'I will love you forever.' She also posted an Instagram story which said: 'My heart is shattered into a million pieces, I don't have the words right now.' 'This world lost one of its kindest, silliest and most genuine of souls this week. Rest easy. I miss you.'\n\nThe US-based couple had travelled from their home in San Diego to Australia over Christmas and New Year, and shared photographs from Melbourne and Perth . The three men had been on a surfing trip down Mexico's west coast. The three men were about 90 minutes' drive south of the US-Mexico border when they disappeared just a few days into the trip. In social media posts shared by Callum just before they vanished, the trio was seen relaxing at Rosarito Beach, where they were said to be surfing and camping as they moved up and down Mexico's west coast.\n\nThey reportedly planned to move on to Ensenada, about 50 miles (80km) down the coast, but concerns were raised when they failed to check into an Airbnb on Sunday. Police said they found three abandoned tents south of Ensenada, which were splattered with blood, according to local media. The brothers' mother issued a desperate plea on social media after the group failed to turn up at an Airbnb they had booked in Rosarito. Mexican authorities also found shell casings at the campsite where the three men were last seen with further investigations leading them to the well about 2km away. Pictyred: Carter Rhoad.\n\nThree bodies, as well as a fourth body believed to be a local rancher, were discovered on Saturday in the clifftop well overlooking the ocean. It is believed the rancher's body had been there for much longer and his death is not believed to be linked to the three young men. It took rescuers up to 20 hours to pull the bodies out of the well, with p hysical characteristics, including hair and clothes, matching the three men. It comes as Attorney-General Mar\u00eda Andrade Ram\u00edrez said the murder investigation would probe whether the men were killed in an attempted robbery. She said the thieves were likely interested in the mens' truck, a white Chevrolet Colorado pickup, and more specifically in the tyres. 'The probability that it's them is very high,' Andrade Ram\u00edrez said. 'When they tried to get the vehicle, the victims opposed the robbery, the robbers were armed with a firearm and apparently shot the victims.'\n\nMs Ramirez added that the victims 'all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile'. Three Mexicans, Jesus Gerardo Garcia Cota, alias El Kekas, his girlfriend, Ari Gisel Garcia Cota (Pictured), and his brother, Christian Alejandro Garcia, were arrested on Wednesday and charged with forced kidnapping. Ms Garc\u00eda Cota, 23, reportedly had one of the missing men's mobile phones. It is understood police were able to make the arrests after one of the brothers' mobile phones was turned back on, and pinged a local mobile tower. All three suspects were found in possession of an assortment of methamphetamines and other illegal drugs, according to local outlets Zeta and Talk Baja.\n\nBaja California, where the men shared their vacation snaps, is known as one of Mexico's most violent, cartel-controlled states. The Robinson brothers had attended Coachella before going to Mexico to surf. Callum was based in the U.S. where he was an accomplished lacrosse player known as 'the Big Koala', and his brother Jake, who worked in regional hospitals across Australia, had flown out to San Diego two weeks ago to visit him. They then allegedly got rid of the bodies by dumping them in a well near the coast.\n\nREAD MORE: Eerie last Instagram post by surfers who mysteriously vanished before chilling discovery\n\nClick for more of the latest news from the Daily Star.\n\nThey said relatives had viewed the corpses recovered from the well about 50ft (15 meters) deep and recognised them as their loved ones.\n\nThe well was located some 4 miles (6 kilometres) from where the foreigners were killed, and also contained a fourth cadaver that had been there much longer. Three suspects are being held in connection with the case.\n\nChief state prosecutor Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez described what likely would have been the group's last moments.\n\nShe theorised that the killers drove by and saw the foreigners' pickup truck and tents and wanted to steal their tyres. But \"when (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\" She said that's when the killers would have shot the tourists.\n\nThe thieves then allegedly went to what she called \"a site that is extremely hard to get to\" and allegedly dumped the bodies into a well they apparently were familiar with.\n\nShe said investigators were not ruling out the possibility the same suspects also dumped the first, earlier body in the well as part of previous crimes.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" Andrade Ramirez said. The thieves allegedly covered the well with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ramirez said, and it took two hours to winch the bodies out of the well.\n\nThe site where the bodies were discovered near the township of Santo Tomas was near the remote seaside area where the missing men's tents and truck were found Thursday along the coast.\n\nFor the latest "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.rnz.co.nz/news/world/516107/australian-brothers-confirmed-dead-in-what-mexican-police-believe-was-car-tyre-heist", "title": "Australian brothers confirmed dead in what Mexican police believe was car tyre heist", "body": "Mexican authorities have positively identified the bodies of three men found in a well in the country's north as two Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nThe parents of Jake and Callum visited the morgue in the Mexican city of Ensenada to identify their sons' bodies earlier on Sunday, local time.\n\nPolice believe the trio were shot dead by thieves who were trying to steal their car for its tyres.\n\nOfficials revealed their early theory about the deaths as members of the surfing community in Ensenada, in Mexico's north-west, took to the streets to demand improved security in the area.\n\nThree people remain in custody over the disappearance of the Robinsons, originally from Perth, and Rhoad, who were camping in Mexico's north-west.\n\nTheir remains were recovered from what had been described as a disused well in the area on Friday.\n\nAll three died from a single gunshot to the head, according to the Baja California Forensic Medical Service.\n\nThat has raised suspicions locally about the possible involvement of drug cartels, which were rife in Baja California.\n\nBut the attorney-general for the Mexican state of Baja California, Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez, told a press conference on Sunday, local time, that authorities' early theory was that the men were killed in a robbery gone wrong.\n\nShe said it appeared the attackers were passing through the area when they decided to steal the campers' ute, which they wanted for its tyres, and they shot the campers when they resisted.\n\n\"They may have been looking for trucks,\" she said.\n\nOn Sunday afternoon, local time, an estimated 500 people marched through Ensenada, chanting in Spanish, \"We want security\".\n\nSome held surfboards with messages including \"Australia, we are with you\" and \"They only wanted to surf, and they executed them\".\n\nLocal surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada said he was marching to call for justice for the men, as well as measures to improve safety at local beaches.\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" he said.\n\n\"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nAnother local, Jorge Emilio Martinez, said the community was outraged over the suspected murders.\n\n\"We feel profound shame and sorrow that this happened in our country,\" he said.\n\n\"We are a country that loves receiving people from all over the world ... this is not who we are as a country.\"\n\nAna Acosta said it had been a rough time for the local surfing community.\n\n\"I'm asking for justice and security from the government and for the state to provide to us surfers,\" she said.\n\n\"You never hear about one girl just going out in the water and surfing, that would be very risky. I want future generations to have the security of going to the ocean and feeling safe.\"\n\nA fourth body was found at the same location as the three suspected to be the campers. But it appeared to have been there for much longer and was not thought to be related, Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nA 23-year-old woman, her partner and his brother were detained last week by Mexican authorities.\n\nOne of the men, named as Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garc\u00eda, now faced a \"forced disappearance\" charge. He had a history of drug dealing, domestic violence and vehicle theft, Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nHis brother and the woman were in custody for possession of methamphetamine.\n\nThe woman was allegedly found with a mobile phone belonging to one of the Australian men.\n\nThe attorney-general said investigators were confident more than three people were involved in the attack.\n\nShe could Local police think the heinous killings happened as the thieves tried to jack their vehicle to steal its tires.\n\nThe bodies of the three surfers were recovered from what had been described as a well in the area last Friday. The Baja California Forensic Medical Service revealed that all three died from a gunshot to the head.\n\nThree men are still in custody over their disappearance. One of them had already been charged with \"forced disappearance\" while the other two are still detained, according to ABC News (Australia).\n\nThe three tourists were surfing in the well-known surf spot of Ensenada, Baja California in Mexico's northwest. Their deaths led to members of the surfing community there, both foreign and local, taking to the streets to demand improved security in the area.\n\nAround 500 people were marching around Ensenada were marching in protest while chanting in Spanish, \"We want security.\" Some of the protesters were holding surfboards with messages including \"Australia, we are with you\" and \"They only wanted to surf, and they executed them.\"\n\n\"We are here in solidarity with our friends from Australia and the United States,\" said local surfer H\u00e9ctor Estrada. \"We are a big community of surfers all over the world and we need security, we need the beaches to be safe [for] camping around, surfing, or just playing with your family, friends.\"\n\nBaja California authorities are calling the incident a \"robbery gone wrong\" as the robbers just wanted to steal the truck the three were riding on to steal their tires. The attack reportedly happened while the three victims were camping on a stretch of beach south of Ensenada.\n\nREAD MORE: Mexico City Searchers Find Massive Clandestine Grave Site Used by Drug Cartels as Crematorium\n\n\"The attackers drove by in their vehicle,\" Baja California chief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez told the media in a press conference. \"They approached, with the intention of stealing their vehicle and taking the tires and other parts to put them on the older-model pickup they were driving.\"\n\nSomehow, the robbery attempt did not go as planned, with the robbers burning the tourists' tents after killing them. They then dumped their bodies into a well before covering it up with boards.\n\nAs to why the robbery attempt went wrong, Andrade Ram\u00edrez noted that the victims may have resisted and this led the robbers to resort to violence.\n\n\"When they (the foreigners) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted,\" she told reporters. \"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then others came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nShe added that the killers might have been looking for trucks. \"They may have been looking for trucks in this area,\" she said. 'I couldn't tell you the number due to secrecy at this time.'\n\nThe attorney general's remarks were made just a day after the families identified the bodies of the surfers.\n\nMar\u00eda Andrade, the of two Australian and one American surfer\n\nAustralian natives Callum and Jake Robison were shot dead along with their California friend Carter Rhoad last week in Baja California, Mexico\n\n30-year-old Californian Jack Carter Rhoad was set to marry his fianc\u00e9e this summer\n\nThe style of the executions have sparked fears locally about the possible involvement of drug cartels which are rife in the region (pictured: the trio's vehicle was later found burnt-out in the Santo Tom\u00e1s area)\n\nTheir bodies were recovered Friday from a 50 feet deep well near La Bocana Beach, in Santo Tom\u00e1s, a town in the municipality of Ensenada Each of the victims had bullet wounds on their heads, according to law enforcement.\n\nJes\u00fas 'El Kekas' Garc\u00eda, his wife Ari Garc\u00eda, and his brother Cristian Garc\u00eda, were arrested in an operation Wednesday.\n\nAuthorities were able to make the arrests after one the Robison brothers' cell phones was turned on and pinged a local mobile tower.\n\nAll three suspects were found in possession of an assortment of methamphetamines and other illegal drugs.\n\nA rescue worker descends into a waterhole where human remains of two Australians and an American were found near La Bocana Beach\n\nThe families of Aussie siblings Callum and Jake Robinson confirmed their bodies Sunday\n\nCarter Rhoad had visited Mexico throughout his adult life after volunteering for a medical mission in Guatemala at 19\n\nThe Robinson siblings and Rhoad, who was slated to be married this summer to his fianc\u00e9e Natalie Wiertz, 32, were supposed to check into an Airbnb in Rosario Beach last weekend after they spent a couple of days camping at La Bocana Beach and last contacted their families April 27.\n\nAndrade said the suspects targeted the surfers because they wanted to steal the pickup truck's tires.\n\nThe state prosecutors said that one of the victims got into a struggle with one of the three suspects, who shot him before gunning down the two other men. Their pickup truck was found burned nearby.\n\nAndrade said that the fact that they were in an uninhabited area made them an easy target.\n\nBrothers Jes\u00fas Garcia Cota and Cristian Garc\u00eda were two of the three arrested. It is unclear which brother is which in their mugshots\n\nAri Garc\u00eda, 23, is one of three suspects arrested. She is reportedly the partner of Jes\u00fas Garcia, who was also arrested\n\nHundreds of people marched through the nearby town of Ensenada on Sunday afternoon, demanding greater security measures amid a welter of cartel-fueled violence (pictured)\n\n'It is a totally remote unpopulated place. There is no communication, no networks, no telephone communication for at least two and a half hours, three inwards,' she explained. 'So, they were very vulnerable.\n\n'The aggressors knew that they could not ask for help and that in order to later report the theft of the vehicle, it would take them more than three hours to reach (people) or where they could ask for help.\n\n'They saw the opportunity that made it easier for them to commit the crime and that is how they tried to steal the vehicle,' Andrade added. 'There was resistance on the part of one of the young men and later they shot him and later the other two were already upset and also scared by what had happened and what had happened to the first of them and they also tried to defend themselves.\n\n'However, these suspects had a firearm.'\n\nAndrade also denied various reports that indicated that the three men had been beaten by the suspects.\n\nWhile some people doubted the robbery motive and suggested it may have been cartel-related, the attorney general stressed all along that the alleged killers were interested in stealing the pickup truck's tires.\n\nIt is believed the region is riven by turf battles between the Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation cartels, in addition to other groups.\n\nIn June last year, the city's If you consent to cookies being set by third-party service providers and that personal data is therefore transferred to third-party service providers, you can allow all cookies and view external content directly.\n\nThe search for two Australian brothers missing in Mexico and their American friend has come to a sad end. After the bodies were found, prosecutors in the state of Baja California believe that the three men, who were on a surfing trip, were shot by thieves who were pursuing their car - especially its tires. Authorities announced on Sunday (local time) that relatives of the missing had identified the dead.\n\nAccording to information, the bodies were already in a state of decomposition after the thieves threw them into a remote well about 15 meters deep. There was also a fourth body in the well, which was said to have been lying there for a long time. \"The possibility that it is them is very high,\" prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez said before the identification was made.\n\nThe three men suddenly disappeared during a camping and surfing trip last week. From their trip, they posted idyllic photos of the waves and remote beaches along the coast south of Ensenada on social media.\n\nAndrade Ramirez described how the journey of Australian brothers Jake and Callum Robinson and American Jack Carter Rudd came to a horrific end. The subsequent killers drove up, saw the trio's pickup truck and tents and decided to steal the tires. \"They definitely defended themselves,\" she said of the victims shot by the robbers.\n\nThe criminals then went to the site where the bodies were found, which was \"extremely difficult to access\" - and threw them into a well, which they apparently knew about in advance. Andrade Ramirez said investigators do not rule out that the suspects may have dumped the other body there. \"It's possible they were looking for trucks in this area.\"\n\nThe site where the bodies were found near the city of Santo Tomas is not far from where the missing people's tents and cars were found on Thursday. The men's recent social media posts gave the impression of a perfect trip. As local surfers from Baha California, we're shaken to the core,\" Baha Surf Club vice president Gino Passalacqua said\n\nAnother local surfer told 7NEWS: \"We ask for security, we ask for justice for these (people).\"\n\nAbout 150 people also gathered for a vigil in San Diego, where Callum lived, according to reports.\n\nThe Robinson brothers were in northern Mexico on a surfing holiday when they failed to check into pre-arranged accommodation near the city of Ensenada.\n\nWA Premier Roger Cook said the situation was incredibly sad for family and friends.\n\n\"Everyone from Western Australia is hurting as we hear from more aspects of this story, the violence they were exposed to and of course the loss of life,\" he said.\n\nCallum was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and Lacrosse Australia said its thoughts were with the loved ones of all three victims.\n\nCallum also played lacrosse at Maryland's Stevenson University and former coach Paul Cantabene said he got along with everyone while being \"big, fast, rigid and flat-out just good\" on the playing field.\n\nJake, a doctor, had ventured overseas to join his brother on the \"trip of a lifetime\".\n\nTheir family travelled to Baja California state in northern Mexico and were taken to view two bodies found at the bottom of a well on a cliff top on Baja Peninsula on Mexico's west coast.\n\nThieves are understood to have killed the three men to steal their truck because they wanted the tyres and then allegedly got rid of the bodies about 6km away.\n\nMexican authorities' preliminary hypothesis is that the surfers resisted being hijacked.\n\nThree suspects are being held in connection with the case, which some locals say authorities had worked to solve far quicker than the disappearances of thousands of Mexicans.\n\nA criminal charge of forced disappearance, equivalent to kidnapping, was laid against one of the three on Saturday.\n\nThe chief state prosecutor's office said evidence found along with abandoned tents at a burnt-out campsite was linked to the three people being questioned.\n\nMedia reported a fourth body found in the well was believed to be that of the property's missing owner.", {"uri": "8113632962", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "10:50:25", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T10:50:25Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T10:49:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://expressdigest.com/callum-and-jake-robinson-shock-theory-emerges-about-the-aussie-brothers-killed-on-a-surfing-trip-in-mexico/", "title": "Callum and Jake Robinson: Shock theory emerges about the Aussie brothers killed on a surfing trip in Mexico", "body": "A shocking new theory about the execution-style deaths of two Australian brothers and their American friend has raised fears over the possible involvement of drug cartels.\n\nCallum and Jake Robinson and their American mate Jack Carter Rhoad were last seen on April 27 in the Mexican province of Baja California.\n\nMexican authorities said bandits attacked the three to steal the tyres off their truck before killing them all and dumping their bodies in a disused well.\n\nBut the style of the slayings - a single gunshot to the head - has sparked fears locally about the possible involvement of drug cartels, which are rife in the region.\n\nThe shock new details emerged as Callum and Jake's grieving parents performed the grim task of identifying their bodies on Sunday.\n\nCallum and Jake Robinson (pictured) and their American mate Jack Carter Rhoad were last seen on April 27 in the Mexican province of Baja California\n\nProsecutors released grisly details of the slayings including that of 30-year-old American Jack Carter Rhoad (pictured)\n\nThe Baja California Forensic Medical Service released the autopsy results as heartbreaking footage emerged of the Aussies' parents leaving the forensics lab after identifying Jake and Jake's bodies.\n\nThree Mexicans have already been arrested over the deaths but authorities are not ruling out further accomplices with possible links to organised crime.\n\n'We cannot rule out the possibility that there are additional individuals who were involved in this incident,' local Attorney-General Mar\u00eda Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nShe added that the victims 'all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile'.\n\nHundreds of people marched through the nearby town of Ensenada on Sunday afternoon, demanding greater security measures amid a welter of cartel-fuelled violence.\n\nCallum and Jake's grieving parents performed the grim task of identifying their bodies on Monday (pictured: the boys' parents leaving the Ensenada Forensics Lab)\n\nSome held surfboards emblazoned with messages written in Spanish, including 'Australia, we are with you' and 'They only wanted to surf, and they executed them', according to the ABC.\n\nBaja California is one of Mexico's most violent states, with the US State Department advising Americans to reconsider travel to the state due to crime and kidnapping.\n\nTijuana, 100km north of where the three surfers were found and close to the US border, is plagued by violence and has the most homicides of any city in Mexico.\n\nWith a population of just over 2 million, it regularly has around 2,000 murders a year.\n\nBy comparison, Houston, Texas, which has a similar population, saw 435 killings in 2022, according to the Associated Press.\n\nHundreds of people marched through the nearby town of Ensenada on Sunday afternoon, demanding greater security measures amid a welter of cartel-fuelled violence (pictured)\n\nJake Robinson (left) is pictured with his brother Callum (right) and their parents - who have flew from Perth to Mexico to identify their bodies\n\nIn December last year, furious drug lords hunted down corrupt officers who allegedly stole a drug shipment.\n\nThe revenge hits led to the deaths of at least five officers.\n\nIt is believed the region is riven by turf battles between the Sinaloa and Jalisco New Generation cartels, in addition to other groups.\n\nIn June last year, the city's mayor, Montserrat Caballero, announced she had decided to live at an army base for her own safety after receiving threats.\n\nDaily Mail Australia previously revealed that Callum's devastated girlfriend Emily Horwath shared a heartfelt tribute on social media.\n\n'You are one of one,' she wrote alongside a photograph of the couple sharing a kiss. 'I will love you forever.'\n\nMexican authorities said bandits attacked the three to steal the tyres off their truck before killing them all and dumping their bodies in a disused well\n\nBut the style of the slayings - a single gunshot to the ead - has sparked fears locally about the possible involvement of drug cartels which are rife in the region (pictured: the trio's vehicle was later found burnt-out in the Santo Tom\u00e1s area)\n\nIt took rescuers up to 20 hours to pull the bodies out of the well, with p hysical characteristics, including hair and clothes, matching the three men (pictured)\n\nShe also posted an Instagram story which said: 'My heart is shattered into a million pieces, I don't have the words right now.'\n\n'This world lost one of its kindest, silliest and most genuine of souls this week. Rest easy. I miss you.'\n\nThe US-based couple had travelled from their home in San Diego to Australia over Christmas and New Year, and shared photographs from Melbourne and Perth.\n\nThe three men had been on a surfing trip down Mexico's west coast.\n\nThe three men were about 90 minutes' drive south of the US-Mexico border when they disappeared just a few days into the trip.\n\nIn social media posts shared by Callum just before they vanished, the trio was seen relaxing at Rosarito Beach, where they were said to be surfing and camping as they moved up and down Mexico's west coast.\n\nCallum's girlfriend Emily Horwath shared a heartfelt tribute on social media (the couple are pictured together on a recent trip to Australia)\n\nThey reportedly planned to move on to Ensenada, about 50 miles (80km) down the coast, but concerns were raised when they failed to check into an Airbnb on Sunday.\n\nPolice said they found three abandoned tents south of Ensenada, which were splattered with blood, according to local media.\n\nThe brothers' mother issued a desperate plea on social media after the group failed to turn up at an Airbnb they had booked in Rosarito.\n\nMexican authorities also found shell casings at the campsite where the three men were last seen with further investigations leading them to the well about 2km away.\n\nThree bodies, as well as a fourth body believed to be a local rancher, were discovered on Saturday in the clifftop well overlooking the ocean.\n\nIt is believed the rancher's body had been there for much longer and his death is not believed to be linked to the three young men.\n\nBrothers Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garcia Cota and Cristian Alejandro Garc\u00eda were two of the three arrested. It is unclear which brother is which in their mugshots\n\nAri Gisel Garc\u00eda Cota, 23, is one of three suspects arrested. She is reportedly the partner of Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garcia Cota, who was also arrested\n\nIt took rescuers up to 20 hours to pull the bodies out of the well, with physical characteristics, including hair and clothes, matching the three men.\n\nIt comes as Attorney-General Mar\u00eda Andrade Ram\u00edrez said the murder investigation would probe whether the men were killed in an attempted robbery.\n\nShe said the thieves were likely interested in the mens' truck, a white Chevrolet Colorado pickup, and more specifically in the tyres.\n\n'The probability that it's them is very high,' Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\n'When they tried to get the vehicle, the victims opposed the robbery, the robbers were armed with a firearm and apparently shot the victims.'\n\nMs Ramirez added that the victims 'all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile'.\n\nThe Robinson brothers attended Coachella before going to Mexico to surf. Callum was based in the U.S. where he was a lacrosse player known as 'the Big Koala', and Jake, who worked in regional hospitals across Australia, had flown out two weeks ago to visit him\n\nThree Mexicans, Jesus Gerardo Garcia Cota, alias El Kekas, his girlfriend, Ari Gisel Garcia Cota, and his brother, Christian Alejandro Garcia, were arrested on Wednesday and charged with forced kidnapping.\n\nMs Garc\u00eda Cota, 23, reportedly had one of the missing men's mobile phones.\n\nIt is understood police were able to make the arrests after one of the brothers' mobile phones was turned back on, and pinged a local mobile tower.\n\nAll three suspects were found in possession of an assortment of methamphetamines and other illegal drugs, according to local outlets Zeta and Talk Baja.\n\nBaja California, where the men shared their vacation snaps, is known as one of Mexico's most violent, cartel-controlled states.\n\nThe Robinson brothers had attended Coachella before going to Mexico to surf.\n\nCallum was based in the U.S. where he was an accomplished lacrosse player known as 'the Big Koala', and his brother Jake, who worked in regional hospitals across Australia, had flown out to San Diego two weeks ago to visit him.\n\nRhoad worked in technology services in San Diego.", "source": {"uri": "expressdigest.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "expressdigest.com"}, a single gunshot to the head - has sparked fears locally about the possible involvement of drug cartels, which are rife in the region.\n\nThe shock new details emerged as Callum and Jake's grieving parents performed the grim task of identifying their bodies on Sunday.\n\nCallum and Jake Robinson (pictured) and their American mate Jack Carter Rhoad were last seen on April 27 in the Mexican province of Baja California\n\nProsecutors released grisly details of the slayings including that of 30-year-old American Jack Carter Rhoad (pictured)\n\nThree Mexicans have already been arrested over the deaths but authorities are not ruling out further accomplices with possible links to organised crime.\n\n'We cannot rule out the possibility that there are additional individuals who were involved in this incident,' local Attorney-General Mar\u00eda Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\nShe added that the victims 'all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile'.\n\nHundreds of people marched through the nearby town of Ensenada on Sunday afternoon, demanding greater security measures amid a welter of cartel-fuelled violence.\n\nSome held surfboards emblazoned with messages written in Spanish, including 'Australia, we are with you' and 'They only wanted to surf, and they executed them', according to the ABC.\n\nThe Baja California Forensic Medical Service released the autopsy results as heartbreaking footage emerged of the Aussies' parents leaving the forensics lab after identifying Jake and Jake's bodies.\n\nCallum and Jake's grieving parents performed the grim task of identifying their bodies on Monday (pictured: the boys' parents leaving the Ensenada Forensics Lab)\n\nHundreds of people marched through the nearby town of Ensenada on Sunday afternoon, demanding greater security measures amid a welter of cartel-fuelled violence (pictured)\n\nJake Robinson (left) is pictured with his brother Callum (right) and their parents - the coast, but concerns were raised when they failed to check into an Airbnb on Sunday.\n\nPolice said they found three abandoned tents south of Ensenada, which were splattered with blood, according to local media.\n\nThe brothers' mother issued a desperate plea on social media after the group failed to turn up at an Airbnb they had booked in Rosarito.\n\nMexican authorities also found shell casings at the campsite where the three men were last seen with further investigations leading them to the well about 2km away.\n\nThree bodies, as well as a fourth body believed to be a local rancher, were discovered on Saturday in the clifftop well overlooking the ocean.\n\nIt is believed the rancher's body had been there for much longer and his death is not believed to be linked to the three young men.\n\nBrothers Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garcia Cota and Cristian Alejandro Garc\u00eda were two of the three arrested. It is unclear which brother is which in their mugshots\n\nAri Gisel Garc\u00eda Cota, 23, is one of three suspects arrested. She is reportedly the partner of Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garcia Cota, who was also arrested\n\nIt took rescuers up to 20 hours to pull the bodies out of the well, with physical characteristics, including hair and clothes, matching the three men.\n\nIt comes as Attorney-General Mar\u00eda Andrade Ram\u00edrez said the murder investigation would probe whether the men were killed in an attempted robbery.\n\nShe said the thieves were likely interested in the mens' truck, a white Chevrolet Colorado pickup, and more specifically in the tyres.\n\n'The probability that it's them is very high,' Andrade Ram\u00edrez said.\n\n'When they tried to get the vehicle, the victims opposed the robbery, the robbers were armed with a firearm and apparently shot the victims.'\n\nMs Ramirez added that the victims 'all have a hole in their head made by a firearm projectile'.\n\nThe Robinson brothers attended Coachella before going to Mexico to surf. AustralianMon, 6 May 2024 5:29PMEmail Sean Smith\n\nSurfers in Baja California have called for justice and improved safety on the region's famed beaches after the shooting deaths of Callum and Jake Robinson and US travelling companion Jack Carter Rhoad.\n\nThe trio were honoured in a late-afternoon, \"paddle-out\" vigil at an Ensenada beach on Sunday that was hosted by the near 60-year-old Baja Surf Club and attended by Mexican and US surfers.\n\nThe club said \"uncertainty, fear, and anguish should not exist\".\n\n\"It's time to raise our voices and come together in a call to action.\"\n\nTheNightlyGet in front of tomorrow's news for FREE\n\nJournalism for the curious Australian across politics, business, culture and opinion.\n\nREAD NOW\n\nIt said the \"paddle-out\" aimed to shine a light on all victims of crime in the region.\n\n\"This goes not only for our fellow surfers who came to visit us but also for all the missing people in Baja California,\" vice president Gino Passalacqua told the San Diego Union-Tribune newspaper.\n\n\"We demand justice and that the authorities do something to stop this.\"\n\nMr Passalacqua told the newspaper the fact that the Australian brothers and Mr Rhoad were killed in a popular spot for surfers underlined the safety concerns.\n\n\"Part of surfing is being able to explore sites in peace and quiet,\" he said.\n\nSurfers were also among scores of demonstrators who marched in Ensenada to voice their anger over the deaths.\n\nMany marched with the surfboards scrawled with messages in Spanish, including \"Australia, we are with you\", \"They only wanted to surf - we demand safe beaches\", \"No more deaths\" and \"Beaches, security, freedom, peace\".\n\nBaja California governor Marina del Pilar \u00c1vila promised \"rigorous\" action against those responsible for the killings, but insisted the popular Mexican state was safe for tourists.\n\n\"Baja California is and will continue to be a state with safe tourism for the thousands of people who visit us from the rest of the country and the world,\" she said.\n\n\"I send my condolences and solidarity to the families in this difficult moment.\"\n\nMexican authorities do not believe the attackers knew the victims were tourists.\n\nMexico recorded more than 30,000 homicides in 2023 for a sixth consecutive year. {"uri": "2024-05-346803162", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "17:46:56", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T17:46:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T17:37:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5254902243614197, "url": "https://www.surfer.com/trending-news/slain-surfers-honored-memorial-paddle-out-baja-locals-call-for-justice", "title": "Slain Surfers Honored with Memorial Paddle-Out in Baja, Locals Call for Justice", "body": "Remembering Aussie brothers Callum and Jake Robinson, and American Jack Carter Rhoad, who were killed while on a surf trip in Mexico.\n\nOver the weekend, a gathering of northern Baja surfers banded together to honor three travelers who were murdered a week before. A memorial paddle-out was held at Playa San Miguel, in addition to calls for justice and increased safety measures.\n\nAustralian brothers Callum (33) and Jake Robinson (30), and American Jack Carter Rhoad (30), were killed while camping at La Bocana, a rural site south of Ensenada. Their bodies were found dumped in a nearby well, and their identities were later confirmed by their families. The cause of death for each was gunshot wounds. Local authorities believe thieves had attempted to steal the tires from their truck, which was found burnt out on a ranch in the area. Three suspects are in custody, and the investigation is ongoing.\n\nMeanwhile, the surf community worldwide is in mourning; and during the demonstrations over the weekend, locals expressed their sadness surrounding the situation, memories of the deceased in the days prior, and demands for action.\n\nHere's a handful of statements from local northern Baja surfers:\n\n\"The unfortunate, horrible events that happened to these three guys, we can all relate,\" said David Kamena, an America living in northern Baja. \"All of us know that camp spot really well. So, this hits home to us. We're calling to the government for more security. It happens every day all over the world, including the US. But we're standing up, and saying we don't like it.\"\n\n\"This horror story happened to some good people, who in their short stay on the beaches of Ensenada left among those of us who had the opportunity to talk with them a great pleasure of meeting people from another world, admired by our country, wanting to listen to traditional music, eat tacos and surf,\" said Beatriz Ibarra, a local surfer with a Master of Science degree. \"Today it was them, yesterday it was others, tomorrow we don't want it to be us. We will continue fighting for a Baja California with decent and safe access and space to all beaches.\"\n\n\"These young men - Callum Robinson, Jake Robinson, and Jack Carter Rhoad - surfed together with a group of us Mexican surfers in the morning at Playa San Miguel, Ensenada B.C.\" remembered Miguel Alc\u00e1zar Sr. \"They were very happy, educated, kind and gentle people. We shared waves and anecdotes.\"\n\nAlc\u00e1zar Sr. continued:\n\n\"Without a doubt Carter was very happy in Playa San Miguel. First, he had a hard time standing on his board and he fell. Callum and Jake were laughing at him and since Carter was just laughing, I approached him and said, 'Can I give you a tip? When you catch the wave and stand up, stay low...' He tried twice and he did it! His friends and I cheered and applauded him. He was still surfing and turned to look at me and he had a face of surprise and happiness. This is how I will remember your friends, who just for that day were also my friends.\"\n\nA GoFundMe account has been created to support the families in this terrible tragedy.\n\n***\n\nDon't miss another headline from SURFER! Officials did not identify the pair.\n\nRam\u00edrez said officials believed the killers saw the victims' tents and pickup truck and wanted to steal their tires, nut when the victims \"came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\"\n\nCalifornia mass shooting: Long Beach shooting injures 7, 4 critically wounded, police say\n\nThe office previously said it learned about the missing friends through social media and announced their bodies were discovered after searching property near where they had been camping in area known as La Bocana Santo Tom\u00e1s.\n\nAt the scene, officials wrote in a release, evidence including tent rods, a gun casing, plastic gallon bottles, blood stains and drag marks, which led to the suspicion that the victims may have been attacked.\n\nU.S. and Australian consulates, embassies and national law enforcement confirmed they have been working closely with the Mexican authorities on the investigation.\n\nThe U.S. Department of State encourages citizens to keep their friends and families aware of their international travels and to discuss plans in the event of an emergency.\n\nNatalie Neysa Alund is a senior reporter for USA TODAY. All three died from a single gunshot to the head.\n\nCallum was a member of Australia's national lacrosse team and Lacrosse Australia said its thoughts were with the families of the Robinson brothers and their friend.\n\n\"Lacrosse Australia is deeply saddened by the deaths of player Callum Robinson, Callum's brother Jake Robinson and their friend Jack (Carter) Rhoad and send our deepest condolences to their families, friends and teammates,\" the association posted on Facebook.\n\nAround 500 people marched through the streets of Ensendada on Sunday (local time) calling for more security in the region.\n\nProtests held surfboards with tributes to Australia saying, \"We are with you\".\n\nOthers marched with the words, \"They only wanted to surf, and they executed them\".\n\nGabriela Acosta, a surfer, told the Associated Press she attended the protest \"to show love, solidarity and respect for the three lives that were lost\".\n\nAcosta said that surfers in Baja are aware of the dangers.\n\n\"We are women and we would sometimes like to surf alone, but we never do that, because of the situation. Violent incident underscores safety concerns in Baja California, despite tourist appeal.\n\nMexican authorities have confirmed the tragic fate of three tourists who went missing in northern Mexico.\n\nThe bodies of American Carter Rhoad and Australian brothers Callum and Jake Robinson were discovered at the bottom of a well in Baja California, ending a harrowing week-long search.\n\nThe trio vanished while on a surfing vacation near the tourist hub of Ensenada, prompting a multi-day search effort.\n\nIdentification of the bodies was facilitated by the victims' parents, eliminating the need for genetic testing.\n\nOfficials from the Baja California state Attorney General's Office pledged a thorough investigation to bring those responsible to justice.\n\nAutopsies revealed that all three victims had suffered gunshot wounds, further intensifying the gravity of the situation.\n\nAustralian Treasurer Jim Chalmers expressed profound condolences to the families, acknowledging the unimaginable ordeal they had endured.\n\nHe condemned the incident as \"absolutely horrendous\" and conveyed the solidarity of the entire nation with the grieving families.\n\nAuthorities have arrested three individuals in connection with the crime, with indications pointing towards a botched carjacking as the motive.\n\nA burnt-out vehicle believed to have been used by the victims was discovered nearby, adding to the grim details of the case.\n\nThe disappearance of the three surfers and the subsequent discovery of their bodies shed light on the persistent safety concerns in Baja California.\n\nDespite the region's popularity among tourists, it remains plagued by violence, prompting warnings from the U.S. State Department urging travelers to exercise caution or reconsider {"uri": "2024-05-346123342", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "07:29:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T07:29:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T05:01:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5137255191802979, "url": "https://www.news.com.au/travel/travel-updates/incidents/tributes-continue-for-slain-aussie-surfers-callum-and-jake-robinson/news-story/46b1d8143a93973a468335a178bef912", "title": "Tributes continue for slain Aussie surfers Callum and Jake Robinson", "body": "Heartbreaking tributes for the Aussie surfers killed in Mexico have emerged after the bodies of Perth-born Jake and Callum Robinson, were found.\n\nThe brothers, aged 30 and 33, were killed in what is understood to have been a robbery gone wrong.\n\nThe pair and their American friend Jack Carter Rhoad, 30, were reported missing last week while camping in the notorious state of Baja California.\n\nTheir bodies were among four found 15m down a hidden well over the weekend, which was located near the last known campsite of the trio.\n\nThe brothers' parents, Martin and Debra Robinson, travelled to Mexico to be close to the search operation, describing their sons as \"beautiful human beings\".\n\nThe couple said Callum had been living in the US to follow his dream of becoming a professional lacrosse player.\n\n\"He is widely known in the US as the Big Koala,\" they said.\n\n\"We think of him as our big, soft, friendly giant.\"\n\nJake only left Australia two weeks ago to visit his brother.\n\n\"It was a trip of a lifetime to see his brother, before shortly taking up a new position at Geelong Hospital in Victoria,\" the parents said.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart.\"\n\nOn Sunday evening Mexico time, local surfing communities gathered to honour the memory of the deceased with a 'paddle out' vigil in the seaside community of San Miguel.\n\nThe vigil included placing flowers on surfboards and paddling out to sea, reflecting the surfing tradition of commemorating fallen comrades.\n\nGino Passalacqua, the vice-president of the Baja Surf Club, said the killings have shattered the community.\n\n\"I'm just shaken to my core,\" he said.\n\nSurfer Phil Brown, who spends four months a year in the area, said he's been pondering how safe the area is in the wake of the tragic event.\n\n\"And that's what's scary is ... did I just get really lucky or did they just get very unlucky?\" he said.\n\nAnother held a sign demanding safer and more accessible beaches in the area.\n\nIn posts on social media, Callum Robinson's partner Emily Horwath shared a series of tributes to her boyfriend from loved ones over the past two days.\n\n\"I'd give anything for one more koala hug,\" she wrote in one post.\n\n\"My heart is shattered into a million pieces. I don't have the words right now.\"\n\nCallum's university team Stevenson University Lacrosse claimed in a social media post the pair had been killed.\n\n\"It is with heavy hearts that we share the news of the passing of our dear teammate and friend, Callum Robinson,\" the club said.\n\n\"From his days leading us to victory on the field to his unwavering commitment to academic excellence, Callum was a true inspiration to us all.\"The club said Callum had played a pivotal role in the team's Division III National Championship in 2013, and had amassed \"equally impressive academic achievements\".\n\nThree suspects arrested as investigation continues\n\nEarlier on Monday, Baja California's Attorney-General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez said it was believed the men were shot in the head while resisting a robbery.\n\nMs Andrade Ramirez said a murder investigation was underway after the bodies were discovered in the well on a cliff overlooking the Pacific Ocean almost a week later.\n\nThree suspects have been charged with offences akin to kidnapping.\n\n\"The attackers drove by in their vehicle,\" Ms Andrade Ramirez said.\n\n\"They approached, with the intention of stealing their vehicle and taking the tyres and other parts to put them on the older-model pickup they were driving.\n\n\"When they (the victims) came up and caught them, surely, they resisted.\n\n\"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then others came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nOn Saturday, authorities identified the three suspects as Jes\u00fas Gerardo Garica Cota (alias El Kekas), his partner Ari Gisel Garc\u00eda Cota, and his brother Cristian Alejandro Garc\u00eda, according to local Spanish language media outlet Zeta Tijuana and Talk Baja.\n\nThey have all been charged with a crime equivalent to kidnapping, officials said.", "source": {"uri": "news.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "News.com.au"}, "authors": [{"uri": "alex_blair@news.com.au", "name": we demand safe beaches\", \"No more deaths\" and \"Beaches, security, freedom, peace\".\n\nBaja California governor Marina del Pilar \u00c1vila promised \"rigorous\" action against those responsible for the killings, but insisted the popular Mexican state was safe for tourists.\n\n\"Baja California is and will continue to be a state with safe tourism for the thousands of people who visit us from the rest of the country and the world,\" she said.\n\n\"I send my condolences and solidarity to the families in this difficult moment.\"\n\nMexican authorities do not believe the attackers knew the victims were tourists.\n\nMexico recorded more than 30,000 homicides in 2023 for a sixth consecutive year. {"uri": "8113740531", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "12:02:05", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T12:02:05Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T12:01:47Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.501960813999176, "url": "https://www.businessinsider.com/men-found-dead-well-mexico-surfers-shot-baja-california-ensenada-2024-5", "title": "3 surfers shot in the head while visiting Mexico were found dead in a well, in an area where tourists are usually safe", "body": "This story is available exclusively to Business Insider subscribers. Become an Insider and start reading now. Have an account? Log in.\n\nJake, 30, had flown to the US to visit Callum, 33, who was pursuing his dream of being a professional lacrosse player. The week after his trip, Jake was due to start a new job as a doctor in Victoria, Australia. Carter Rhoad, 30, was working as an apparel designer in San Diego, the New York Post reported.\n\nThey were last seen on 27 April and, when they didn't show up to an Airbnb booking a couple of days later, were reported missing and an investigation was launched by local authorities and the FBI.\n\nIt's thought that the tourists were attacked after they defended themselves from three people who were trying to steal their truck.\n\nBaja California state prosecutor Maria Andrade suggested that the attackers wanted the truck for its tires and shot the three men in their heads when they resisted, Reuters reported.\n\nA burnt-out vehicle suspected to be the surfers' truck was also found in the area, alongside abandoned tents, and a phone linked to them.\n\nThree Mexican nationals, two men and a woman, have been arrested as suspects.\n\nA fourth body was also found in the well, but it's believed to be older and from an earlier incident, the Guardian reported.\n\nTurf wars between drug gangs are common in Baja California, which is one of Mexico's most dangerous and violent states. However, Ensenada is generally considered to be safe -- about 75 miles south of California, it is a popular spot for US tourists.\n\nFriends and family of the Robinsons and Carter Rhoad have been sharing tributes to the young men.\n\n\"Callum and Jake are beautiful human beings. We love them so much and this breaks our heart,\" the brothers' parents said in a statement, the BBC reported.\n\nCallum's teammates from Stevenson University Lacrosse Club said in a statement on social media: \"With his beautiful long hair and charming smile, he truly embodied the nickname 'big koala' -- warm, friendly, and always there to lend a helping hand.\"\n\nHis girlfriend, Emily Horwath, said in an Instagram story that her heart was \"shattered into a million pieces.\"\n\n\"I don't have the words right now... I will love you forever,\" she wrote.\n\nProtesters and mourners took to the streets of Ensenada on Sunday to share their sadness and anger.\n\nThey marched with messages on surfboards, such as \"They only wanted to surf -- we demand safe beaches.\"\n\nSurfers also held a \"paddle out\" ocean vigil in memory of the Robinsons and Carter Rhoad.", "source": {"uri": "businessinsider.com", "dataType": I don't have the words right now,\" she wrote in a series of Instagram stories dedicated to her later boyfriend.\n\n\"You are one of one. I will love you forever.\n\n\"Truly one of the most beautiful and loving souls. There aren't words. We love you so much.\"\n\nThe couple had been based in the United States city of San Diego, where Callum had moved to represent Australia playing professional lacrosse on an international level.\n\nA GoFundMe page has been set up to help support the parents, Martin and Debra Robinson.\n\n\"In the wake of the heartbreaking loss of Callum Robinson and Jake Robinson, our hearts ache with grief for their families, friends, and community. Their presence brought immeasurable joy, love, and kindness to those around them, leaving a mark on our lives,\" the page read.\n\nSeveral friends of the Robinson brothers also shared their heartbreak at the untimely deaths.\n\n\"The world is cruel and unfair, but you were not. Heaven has the best,\" Kate Beber wrote to her story.\n\nFederal Treasurer Jim Chalmers addressed the \"horrendous\" news in his Monday morning press conference, offering his condolences to the men's friends and family.\n\n\"We can only imagine what this ordeal has been like for them and for the loved ones of Callum and Jake,\" he said.\n\n\"I think the whole country's heart goes out to all of their loved ones. It has been an absolutely horrendous, absolutely horrific ordeal and our thoughts are with all of them today.\"\n\nLarge rallies were staged in Mexico's Ensenada over the weekend, with locals and members of the surfing community marching in solidarity with the Australians and American killed.\n\nProtesters called for better protection of touring foreigners and shared frustration at the brazen actions of the thieves.\n\nEarlier on Monday, police said the three people in custody over the incident had been charged with forced kidnapping over what was an attempted robbery gone wrong, with gang violence not being a line of inquiry in the early stages of the investigation.\n\nBaja California's Attorney-General Maria Elena Andrade Ramirez said the thieves may have been looking for trucks to steal in the area, before they spotted the men's campsite and car and proceeded to rob them.\n\n\"The perpetrators drove by and saw the foreigners' ute and tents and wanted to steal their tyres,\" she told a press conference, according to local media reports.\n\n\"The perpetrators approached with the intention of taking over the ute to remove the tyres, and put them on their older car. It is likely that there was resistance on the part of the tourists, and the aggressors took out a weapon in their possession.\"\n\nMs Ramirez said the victims had been found with a single gunshot wound to the head each in an \"execution-style\" killing.\n\nNorthern Mexico is listed as a high-risk zone for travel on the Australian government's Smartraveller website with crimes, including murder, armed robbery, sexual assault, kidnapping, and extortion cited as common threats.\n\nForeign Affairs Minister Penny Wong and Prime Minister Anthony Albanese have not yet commented on the incident. "What makes Mexico so unsafe for travellers", "body": "READ MORE: Shocking update after two Australians and their American friend vanish without a trace while in Mexico\n\nFor many Australian travellers, the appeal of visiting Mexico is so strong that they set aside the very real safety concerns, but the alleged murder of two surfer brothers is likely to put off even the most fearless would-be visitor.\n\nThe alleged murders of Perth brothers Callum and Jake Robinson and American surfing buddy Jack Carter Rhoad in the Mexican state of Baja California has exposed just how risky it is to visit the nation, which is racked by ruthless violent crime.\n\nThe Smart Traveller website provided by the Australian Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade warns Australians visiting Mexico are at a high risk of violent crime, including murder, armed robbery, carjacking, sexual assault and kidnapping, especially after dark.\n\nIt advises these violent crimes can even occur at tourist spots and resorts.\n\nThe northern border state of Baja California, where the bodies of the trio and another ranch manager were found in a 50-foot well, is one of the states with higher risk, due to drug cartels and people-smuggling gangs trying to get their products into the US.\n\nAustralian brothers Callum, 33 (left) and Jake, 30, were last seen with their American friend on April 27\n\nProsecutors released grisly details of the slayings, but have not yet officially confirmed the identification of the bodies, including 30-year-old American Jack Carter Rhoad\n\nMr Talmi told Daily Mail Australia that while Mexico Is a beautiful country, it is challenging from a security point of view and tourists should be extremely vigilant\n\nA woman and two men have been arrested, though the charges have not yet been finalised.\n\nAuthorities believe the deaths stemmed from a vehicle robbery that escalated to the point that shots were fired.\n\nProsecutors released grisly details of the slayings, and today confirmed the families have positively identified their bodies.\n\nThe Mexican government has been fighting but largely losing its \"War on Drugs' since December 2006, when newly elected President Calderon deployed more than 6,500 soldiers to his home state of Michoac\u00e1n to battle drug traffickers.\n\nA 2022 research paper by Justice in Mexico an organisation that works to improve citizen security, strengthen the rule of law, and protect human rights in Mexico reveals some insight into the Baja California area.\n\nThe paper states that the area 'has been and remains an important focal point for violence and organized crime in Mexico.'\n\n'The public security challenges facing Baja California remain significant,' the paper states.\n\n'Communities continue to be impacted by elevated levels of violence, and emerging patterns in violent crime incidence serve as a reminder of persistent volatility in the security situation.'\n\nEltan Talmi, a security expert and founder and CEO of US-based security company Tactical Troop, agrees.\n\nMr Talmi told Daily Mail Australia that while Mexico Is a beautiful country, it is challenging from a security point of view and tourists should be extremely vigilant.\n\nHe said 'Most of the places, you would be able to visit, live or even work without feeling any threat or risk.'\n\nMr Talmi advises tourists to follow the advice of local authorities, avoid isolated areas, be careful after dark and avoid dealing with unknown people.\n\nHe said the violence in Mexico is mainly carried out by warring cartels and criminal groups battling for control of the cities.\n\nProsecutors released grisly details of the slayings, and today confirmed the families have positively identified their bodies.\n\nAccording to local media, blood was discovered at three abandoned tents where the brothers and their American friend were believed to be staying before they vanished. A truck, said to belong to either Jake or Callum, was also found burnt out at a nearby farm (pictured)\n\nThe corpses were decomposing after the thieves dumped them into a remote, 50- foot deep well\n\nMr Talmi said that areas like Baja California are of special concern for tourists as they are very isolated with low government presence.\n\n'Tourists should exercise extra safety measures to mitigate the risk,' he said.\n\nHis advice for Australian tourists to make their trip to Mexico more safe is to always understand local culture and behaviour.\n\n'Many tourists from many parts of the world believe they can behave the same as they do in their home country without understanding the culture,' he said.\n\nMr Talmi suggests tourists to Mexico should call for assistance or report anything that made them feel unsafe and request security support.\n\nEven with the tragic incident of the two Australian brothers, he said Australians should still travel to Mexico, but to 'always check with a reliable source about the places they are planning to visit and not become a victim.'\n\nEitan Talmi quotes:\n\n- Mexico, as most of the Latin American countries, are a challenge regarding to security. Most of the places, you would be able to visit, live or even work without feeling any threat or risk. Dealing or doing any kind of business with unknown people, or staying on remote areas can lead anyone to front risks or problems that they would like to avoid.\n\n- The violence in Mexico is mostly regarding Cartels and criminal groups activities, Their war for the control of the plazas, may affect the regular life of the Mexican people and also of tourist.\n\nAre there areas tourists should avoid?\n\n- Mexico Is a beautiful country, but as most of LATAM cities, tourist should avoid isolate areas, moving on night hours and dealing with unknown people.\n\nAre the major sites and tourist destinations ok for tourists?\n\n- Yes, people just need to avoid specific areas, or be related to unknown persons or do any kind of business with unknowns.\n\nWhat can Australian tourists do to make their trip to Mexico more safe?\n\n- Always check with a reliable source about the places they are planning to visit. - When possible, receive support and assistance in the planning and during the trip.\n\n- They need to ensure that they understand the local culture and behavior. Many tourist from many parts of the world believe they can behave as same they will do it in their home country without understanding the culture, or who the person in front of them will receive the message of what the person is doing.\n\n- Call for any assistance or report any case they feel unsafe and request security support.\n\n(do you believe tourists are safer in the major tourist areas?)\n\n- If they follow the recommendations and avoid problematic places or situations - YES.\n\n(Should Australian tourists still travel to Mexico?)\n\n- Yes. Just need to understand the situation and not become a victim.\n\n(Is it mainly the isolated areas that are the problem?)\n\nYes. Isolated areas with low government presence are a issue.\n\n(Is the Baja California area of special concern? {"uri": "2024-05-346838182", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-05-06", "time": "18:29:47", "dateTime": "2024-05-06T18:29:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-05-06T14:24:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-05-06/how-a-beach-trip-in-mexicos-baja-california-turned-deadly-for-surfers-from-australia-and-the-us", "title": "How a Beach Trip in Mexico's Baja California Turned Deadly for Surfers From Australia and the US", "body": "MEXICO CITY (AP) -- Two Australians and an American were doing what they loved on the stunning, largely isolated stretch of Baja California's Pacific coast. Their last images on social media showed them sitting and gazing at the waves, contemplating the breaks.\n\nWhat happened to end their lives may have been as random as a passing pickup truck full of people with ill intent. The surfers were shot in the head, their bodies dumped in a covered well miles away. How it unfolded was the stuff of nightmares.\n\nBrothers Jake and Callum Robinson from Australia and American Jack Carter Rhoad had apparently stopped to surf the breaks at Punta San Jos\u00e9, about 50 miles (80 kilometers) south of Ensenada. They were attacked there on April 28 or 29.\n\nAs soon as police arrived at their last known camp site, it was clear that something had gone violently wrong.\n\nThere were bloodstains and marks \"as if heavy objects had been dragged,\" leading to suspicions of an attack, the Baja California state prosecutor's office said in an attempt to reconstruct the scene.\n\nChief state prosecutor Mar\u00eda Elena Andrade Ram\u00edrez told a press conference on Sunday that the killers apparently drove by, saw the foreigners' pickup truck and wanted to steal its tires and other parts.\n\nSuch was the banality of evil, she said, that \"they were not attacked because they were tourists. ... The evidence suggests they (the killers) did not know where they were from.\"\n\nThe foreigners surely resisted, she said. \"And these people, the assailants, took out a gun, and first they killed the one who was putting up resistance against the vehicle theft, and then the other two came along and joined the fight to defend their property and their companion who had been attacked, and they killed them too.\"\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez said the reconstruction of events was based on the forensic examiner's reports, noting all three had bullet wounds to the head.\n\nThere was a hurried attempt to destroy evidence. The foreigners' tents were apparently burned. The pickup truck was driven miles away and burned. The assailants' truck was later found with a gun inside.\n\nThen, at \"a site that is extremely hard to get to,\" the bodies were dumped into a well about 4 miles (6 kilometers) away. Investigators were surprised when, underneath the bodies of the three foreigners, a fourth body was found that had been there much longer.\n\n\"They had to have previous knowledge of it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said of the attackers, acknowledging the possibility they were behind the previous killing.\n\nThe well had been covered with boards. \"It was literally almost impossible to find it,\" Andrade Ram\u00edrez said. It took two hours to winch the bodies out.\n\nProsecutors have said they were questioning three people in the killings. Two were caught with methamphetamines. One of them, a woman, had one of the victims' cellphones when she was caught. Prosecutors said the two were being held pending drug charges but continue to be suspects in the killings.\n\nA third man was arrested on charges of a crime equivalent to kidnapping, but that was before the bodies were found. It was unclear if he might face more charges.\n\nThe third man was believed to have directly participated in the killings. In keeping with Mexican law, prosecutors identified him by his first name, Jes\u00fas Gerardo, alias \"el Kekas,\" a slang word that means quesadillas, or cheese tortillas.\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez said he had a criminal record that included drug dealing, vehicle theft and domestic violence, adding, \"We are certain that more people were involved.\"\n\nShe emphasized that she could not discuss anything related to the suspects, or their possible statements, because that was not allowed under Mexican law and might prejudice the case against them.\n\nAndrade Ram\u00edrez noted that the victims' families said the brothers and Rhoad had come many times to the seaside spot and never had any problem. This time, however, \"there was no way to ask for help when the attackers showed up.\"\n\nCopyright 2024 The Associated Press. All rights reserved.
